At 09:27 AM 4/7/02 +0100, Nick Hempshall wrote:
>Kevin Smith grafo
>> Back to my original sentence: ~mi volu auxi~ (I want to
>> help). It seems that it is nearly _impossible_ to use auxi
>> as a verb, because it will be interpreted as a noun.
>> Instead, you must say ~mi volu dona auxi~. It bothers me
>> somewhat to have a word that could perfectly legitimately
>> mean "to help" unusuable in that role.
>
>I think this is to do with the semantics of ~volu~, which
>has the implication of wanting to receive something,
>rather than to the syntax.
>
>~Mi volu aqa.~ [I want (some) water.]
>~Mi volu auxi.~ [I want (some) help.]
>~Mi volu bibe.~ [I want to drink.]
>~Mi volu dona auxi.~ [I want to help.]
>
>Compare ~tende~
>
>~Mi tende bibe.~ [I intend to drink.]
>~Mi tende auxi.~ [I intend to help.]
>~Mi tende gene auxi.~ [I intend to be helped.]
>
*   This seems very well observed by Nick.  The 'semantics' do seem to play
a big part in the use of a language with "Syntax-based Grammar."
    Here ~tende~ plays the part of a VERBOID, but ~volu~ does not seem to
bend so easily to the Verboid function.
    While some of us wish to use this concept as a Verboid, we might, while
it is still in the GID, use the abbreviated form ~vo~ for this purpose.
   EG   Ka mi vo auxi an, mi pa ki ad an domi. 
   Because I wished to help him, I went to his house.

    I imagine ~vo~ might be  =  wish, would( will-do).

Saluta,

Robin

sid wrote
> feno x holo ge-lose

x = "to be" = ~es~

> Mi pa sti ki a hoteli ubi (qo-lo) u mi fe-sponsa e plu ami pa atende.

"where" as a conjunction is really ~qi-lo~ [which place].

~U hoteli; qi-lo mi gina pa atende;~ [The hotel; where my wife waited]
or perhaps better put as
~U hoteli; in qi mi gina pa atende;~ [The hotel; in which my wife waited]

Plu ami saluta ex
Nick

> Ron Clark did recognise this creolisation process, and its trend
> towards a language that was intuitive and concept based; he tried, with
> Glosa, to push the structure of language towards the conclusion of this
> intuitional process.  Experience on Glosalist makes me wonder if the human
> race is ready, yet, for this stage of language development.

I agree with the view of Glosa as a euro-creole. So did the speakers
of the Lingua Franca for over 800 years. And according to Bickerton,
creoles are closer to the human "proto-language". The compiler of
Occidental also believed that Europeans generally are evolving their
languages toward analytic syntax.

> SE  - maybe a separate word in Glo, but was incorporated into
> Glosa to give 'the reflexive,'

SE is a reflexive particle in many euro-langs, except, it has really
become more of a passive than a reflexive, which is very confusing.
I think that in Glosa the passive is maybe GE or ES rather than SE.

>> I have tentatively added my first non-Glosa word to Glo:
>> ~susta~, meaning: sustain, support, prop (support), hold up

We're back to those Roman "super-productive" morphemes again ...
SUB + STARE = English "to sustain" = (poetic) "hold up from below".
I once counted something like 20 productive prefixes that combine
with 200 or so stems to produce thousands of latinate words from
amazingly few elements. That's a good derivational system.

> The brief ~susta~ is adequate for Glo, whilst I might prefer, for
> Glosa, something a little longer, indication the derivation, such as -
> ~sustene~

TEN- forms a different word-family in Latin. But I agree that
the usual CVCV pattern is inadequate for super-productives.
In fact, experimentation shows that CVCVC (3 separate consonant
clusters) are needed to disambiguate most of the euro-vocab.
However STA is exceptional and I find SUSTA not bad actually ...

> I might put in a plug for my theory that
> the brain needs time to process the sounds it inputs,

I kinda agree with that theory (so maybe you should reconsider it).
Longer content words and shorter particles, for smoother digestion.

> As well, ~sustene~ looks like a different word from ~tena~, whereas
> ~sustena~ might look like a compound.

Follow the Latin spellings rather than false phoneticity and then
suSTA beats susTEN. Better to go completely apriori than to disguise
the well-known roots of our shared Greco-Latin culture. I mean,
adoption of euro-vocab is good but mangling it is counter-mnemonic.

>
>Me too!
>
>I was speaking about the "underlying" form and not
>the form I would use.
>
*   The question of optionality comes in here: is the N(sing/pl) marker a
space-filler that is called upon to indicate the NP's start in the absence
of any meaningful NP indicator (assuming that disambiguation is necessary),
or is the N(sing/pl) always assumed to be there and ready to pop through,
no matter how redundant it might be?
    My guess is that this moves over to the realms of the computer handling
of language.  If we are going to raise Glosa to the level of a 'Query
Language' then this "grammar" will be somewhat different from the
Humanly-usable, Glosa Grammar; and, the former will carry the coded
instruction that the suitable NOUN(Singular/Plural) particle must be
inserted at the start of any Noun Phrase, when no alternative NP Indicator
is present.

Saluta,

Robin

Kenton ki u longi ge-atende visita a Brookfield e u
juve babi; Ben. An habe u moli ludi-ra wombat
(Faskolomio Wombat) te dona a Ben. An dice a
Elizabeth; an vive es mali, kompara u vive de David.
An dice; an gina; Mel; linqi an po fe detekti-se u
tipika rugo Aussie andro.

Heather; u matri de Ruth; kuko u di-mo meso-vora; anti
id es fe fini di a Brookfield. Ruth fu este u minus;
kron fe matri fu re-ki a fe domi. David ne este hedo
de visita de Kenton. An qestio-se; qo-te an re-veni a
Britain.

Kento ami ludi ko plu infanti; e, feno, an veri este u
minus de Meriel; an juve fe-fili. Kenton e David dura
este ge-prepara disputa alelo - David ma forti kausa
fatiga. Anti-co, mu nega u ofere de Kenton de auxi
karpe lakti. Kenton dice a simpati Heather; Mel pa
detekti-se u latino amo-pe ex Italia famili. Kenton
tende visita Shula fu-di. Fe ne feno es boni reakti
plu problema de Daniel a sko-do.

(C) BBC

--- "Nick Hempshall" <nick{at}hempshall{dot}fsbusiness{dot}co{dot}uk> wrote:
> ~an vive~  =  ~u vive de an~ [the life of him]
> ~an~ can start a noun phrase as well as be 
> a pronoun and be followed by a verb. 
> 
> ~u an vive~ would mean "the male life".

Or "a/the man's life", which is certainly close to "his life".

This is why Glo now has SA to indicate posession. Also, currently, Glo splits 
he/him (AN) from man/male/masculine (ANDRO). So, in Glo:
~an sa vive~ = his life
~u andro sa vive~ = a/the man's life
~u andro vive~ = a/the masculine life

SA has been a surprisingly pleasant and powerful addition to Glo, and I have 
very quickly embraced it both as a writer and as a reader. I heartily recommend 
that Glosa adopt something similar.

Kevin

A "male life" could be "an-vive" (like "fe-bovi" ...).
I am still not convinced and would agree with Syd:
With the order

  <noun phrase marker u(n)/plu> +
  <attributes, also possessive pronouns> +
  ...
  <main concept word, noun>

the noun phrase could be easier acknowledged.

Another argument: appositions.

Wrong (but IMO better) Glosa:
  "Mi ne amo plu vi simi."  - I do not like your apes.
Classical Glosa:
  "Mi ne amo vi plu simi."  - I do not like your apes.
Apposition:
  "Mi ne amo vi, plu simi." - I do not like you apes.

ne fu vendo. U merka-pe in boteka pa bali u mero ex fe
stoma ko fo-non-amo; kron fe pa gusta un exempla.
Helen pa dice; fe tende; u kasea habe akidi; sed u
merka-pe qestio; qe fe tende; id toxi plu merka-pa.
Helen este fo-non-hedo; sed fe fu dona u kasea a Tom
te plus u vora-ma pro plu sui. 

Kenton dice a Pat e Clarrie; an pa vide Roy in 
bibli-do ko kumu de histori bibli; ka an kredi; 
Hayley habe mega interese de histori; e mu fu ki a
Hereford te skope u "Mapa Mundi". Kenton dice a mu 
de Mel; fe linqi an pro "Greko Teo"; un andro ko
Hellas patri.

Joe proto repara u horti de Jennifer e Brian; 
qi "Baby Spice" pa noku. An habe nuli butiri ex fe
lakti; an tende dona a mu; ka, anti-lega, Eddie pa
vendo id. Jennifer fo non-amo plu neo horti orna-ra;
ge-face ex Eddie; e fe komanda; Joe apo mu. Anti-co,
an pa fixa mu per cementa te sto hetero bovi noku mu.

SA (~sa~) is a Glo (not Glosa) word. In Glo (not Glosa):

~u parenta sa zoa~ = a parent's animal

The first sentence is ambiguous in Glosa.

sati akti, ci-tem, kura plu infanti e u juve babi. Si

habe u brevi-tem ergo-pe.

--- Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:
> I thought my newly assembled GE dictionary was comprehensive 
> but it hasn't G for Mister, Sir, steep. Any offers?

18 Steps and the Glosa Basic Reference list ~Sinior~ for mister (abbreviated 
~Sr.~), and they list ~Siniora~ and ~Siniorina~ for miss/mrs/ms, all abbreviated 
as ~Sa.~ The GID shifts these to ~senior~ and ~seniora~

Of course, distinguishing the marital status and perhaps youthfulness of women 
but not men is a pointless, sexist cultural artifact, and should not be carried 
into Glosa.

There is a suggestion in 18 steps (presumably added by Marcel?) that proposes 
~Civi~, ~An-civi~, and ~Fe-civi~ as better honorific terms.

Glo (not Glosa) currently has ~an~ for mr. and ~fe~ for miss/ms/mrs. For 
example: ~mi pa dona plu sito ad fe Brown.~ I'm not sure if Glo will keep these 
or shift to something else. As a member of a "younger generation" and a resident 
of a very casual culture, I'm not big on honorifics.

As for "steep", I assume you mean "sharply inclined", and not "allowing tea to 
strengthen". The GID has ~fo-klina~ as a core word for steep.

Kevin

Subject: [glosalist] adverbs
From: Kevin Smith <kevins{at}qualitycode{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 05 May 2002 06:30:43 -0700

While playing around with the BNF model for Glo, I realized that adverbs in 
Glosa seem to be all over the place. I would like to restrict them to a single 
location in Glo. My definition of "adverb" here is: any word or phrase that 
modifies the verb.

Here's what I see in Glosa right now:

~mi pa tako gresi.~
~mi pa mite u nota ad tu.~ (~ad tu~ is the adverb)
~pre nu, mi pa gresi.~ (~pre nu~ is the adverb)
~qo mode, mi pa gresi?~ (~qo mode~ is like an adverb)

It seems that every possible structure of English has been allowed into Glosa, 
which makes things much more complex than they need to be.

Following the rule that modifiers precede head words, we would have something 
like:

~mi pa tako gresi.~
~mi pa, ad tu, gresi.~
~mi pa pre-nu gresi.~
~mi pa qo mode gresi?~

Perhaps it's reasonable to say that if the "adverb" begins with a preposition, 
it can follow the verb, since we already have that rule for nouns. But does it 
go before or after the object?

~mi pa mite u nota ad tu~
~mi pa mite ad tu u nota~

The first is more comfortable for me, but I'm not sure it is any more logical or 
clear. Why not: ~mi pa ad tu mite u nota~, or even ~ad tu, mi pa mite u nota.~

I'm sure some of you feel that this flexibility is crucial to the success of 
Glosa, because without it authors will feel too constrained. Even if that were 
true (and I disagree), I believe that there should be just one "recommended" or 
"standard" form.

I'm going to go off and read Rick Morneau's pages, but I thought I would toss 
this question out to the list to see what people think.

Kevin

> My definition of "adverb" here is: any word or phrase that
> modifies the verb.

There are at least 4 types of "adverbs" as far as I know:
you left out sentence modifiers (like "hopefully, ...")
and adjective modifiers (like "VERY wet"). Your definition
would include adverbial phrases (like "in a pig's eye")
and regular verb modifiers (like "he NEVER saw it").

> It seems that every possible structure of English has been allowed into Glosa,
> which makes things much more complex than they need to be.

English has complex syntax, completely unsuitable for an IAL.

> Perhaps it's reasonable to say that if the "adverb" begins with a preposition,
> it can follow the verb, since we already have that rule for nouns. But does it
> go before or after the object?

Any phrase can be topicalized by placing it first in the sentence.
The direct object usually has the closest tie to the verb and so
should immediately follow it; I think it should take a special
preposition (perhaps "em"?) whenever it strays from normal position,
just as the agentive subject does (using "per" or "ex" or "ab").

> I'm sure some of you feel that this flexibility is crucial

Flexibility competes with simplicity. All languages are compromises ...
except Lisp.

Subject: [glosalist] adverbs
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com

Syd said:

> in a SVO sentence, an adjective should be close to the N it modifies
> or there would be confusion.

So a noun phrase gets a pseudo-BNF description something like:
"NP = preposition + determininers + adjectives + noun + NPs"
.. i.e., NPs are recursive. In some languages the noun's
modifiers can be scattered all across the sentence randomly,
but Glosa is extremely order-dependent.

> An adverb can be more or less anywhere as there is only
> one V in the clause.

Not precisely so, because it can be unclear what it attaches to.
Even a proper "adverbial" phrase that wanders can be ambiguous:
"He chased the dog WITH a broomstick IN his underwhere."

> I rather like the idea that, as V, S and O have intro
> particles, so could adjective and adverb phrases

Me too. But the positions of those phrases should be constrained.
English is unusual in its high degree of syntactic ambiguity,
and this should not be imported to Glosa.

> further I should like to be
> able to use particles that define S and O

I agree. Whenever sentence phrase order is unusual, use of
prepositions removes the unclarity. We already have "per"
and "ex", only the direct object lacks one. (I think "de"
might be used immediately following the verb, but that's
not what we need here.) Otto Jesperson proposed "em",
and in Ido they use "na", IIRC.

>KS> While playing around with the BNF model for Glo, I realized that

 It seems that every possible structure of English has been allowed into

*   Well, I answer in English, because the answer promises to be tricky.
    Yes, in English the text book location for adverbs is AFTER the verb.
 EG  He ran quickly to work.
    But, quite pragmatically, if the Verb Phrase is going to become
awkwardly overloaded through the addition of excessive adverbs, then some
of the adverbs get shunted to the front, or the tail, of the sentence as
much-elided Adverbial Clauses.
         EG  While still eating breakfast, he ran quickly to work, heavily
overloaded.
         If RAN is the action,
                QUICKLY,
                WHILE STILL EATING BREAKFAST, and
                HEAVILY OVERLOADED
all modify this action.

   Can Glosa also spread its 'adverbial' modifiers around in a similar
fashion?  I cannot see why not!
   If we rigidify Glosa's structure (or try to), thus making it 'inhuman',
we might get something equvalent to,
  EG  He ran quickly, while still eating breakfast and heavily overloaded,
to work.

  In Glosa, modifiers precede the word they modify ('adjectives' before
'nouns'; and 'adverbs' before 'verbs'): note, there being no Part-of-Speech
markers in Glosa, ~celero~ is used to translate both "fast" and "quickly." 

  IE  An pa kurso celero, tem du fago an prima vora, e fero excesi masi, ad
an ergo-lo.   [Adverb content AFTER the verb as in English]

Or putting modifiers, where they should be in Glosa, BEFORE the 'verb',
      An celero, tem du fago an prima vora, e fero excesi masi, pa kurso ad
an ergo-lo.  

  But it might be kinder to the listener to break up the Adverbial element
to give him, or her, psychological time to absorb the various modifications
to the action.

  IE  Du fago an prima vora, e du fero excesi masi, an pa celero kurso, ad
an ergo-lo.

   I would hate to say that the BNF model, being only artificially
intelligent, could possibly suffer from an excessive need for
standardisation.  And it might be Politically Incorrect to suggest that
good Glosa, being planned to make sense, ultimately, to human beings,
possibly will not fit a rigidified structure.  However, I do venture such
thoughts.

>mi nu habe u qestio. qo ex u face fu es korekti?
>

But practical too. A few years ago I wrote a web CGI translation
assistant for Glosa-to-English. Instead of attempting the impossible,
it simply takes a paragraph of Glosa text and generates a *glossary*.
The output side can be adapted very easily to any other language.
And the input side works with Ido and similar IALs.

> I have added x, s, c, v, o temporarily

> from this bridge, one could produce idiomatic E

I think you are attempting to reinvent the sentence parse tree,
or maybe a part-of-speech tagger, or both. These are inherently
difficult and complicated though interesting as tools of analysis.
If a program could input one natural language and output another,
it would be done already, and there'd be no need for an IAL.

>Robin flogs Syd with relative clauses ...
>
>>    .....
>> The 'mass action effect' is the only hope for those of us who value the
>> presence of what I call the 'logical "that"' in a language.
>
>Relative clauses are a difficult problem for the language designer to
>solve. It requires a lot of study of actual world languages to do right.
>I've already recommended that everyone study Rick Morneau's site,
>especially his essay on "Syntax"; 
*   The "that" of English has two incarnations: everybody know about the
one which starts 'relative clauses'; but the other one is harder to pin
down.  In English, I notice that I seem to use it more than most.  That I
seem to use it more than most, is noticable, in my use of English.
    This second use appears to be associated with the verb, rather than
with a noun.  And the "that" is used somewhat as a mathematical
"therefore."  When I use Glosa, I wish to be similarly specific; thus, I
have not yet been convinced that the Old Glosa ~ke~ is useless, and must go.


>             Glosa relies almost entirely on syntax,
>and the current semicolonic mishmash is probably the single most glaring
>error in its grammar, yet is so easy to fix ...
>
*   While some feel (that) the semicolon is evil, I see it as no more than
a mark of punctuation with a 'pausal factor' somewhere between that of the
comma and the colon.  Ron and Wendy chose it to demark clauses, wheras, if
it is necessary to do so necessary, most of us would use the          comma
to separate phrases.  Because clauses have greater significance, the
authors chose to mark them with a divider of greater power than that of the
simple comma.  So, I will not mention the semicolon again, I shall simply
continue to use it the way the Glosa authors thought appropriate.

>[re-formatted examples follow:]
>
>> His story was that he was sick.
>> An histori pa es ke an pa habe pato.
>
>How about using the officially blessed CO and QOD or even just DE?
>
>"An pa dice de an pato." -- "He spoke of his (own) sickness."
>"An pa dice de an anas es pato." -- "He talked about his duck being sick."
>"An es pato, (u-)co an pa dice." -- "He (is/was) sick, that's what he said."
>
*  Because of Glosa's newness, and of its "economy" with grammar, it needs
some spelling out of the meanings in its sentences: I believe that, at the
start, we can introduce some abbreviations of usage, but to expect that we
can 'force' the elisions that have evolved over the centuries with English,
onto Glosa, is presumptuous.
   An es pato.*            An habe pato.
  [he is sick(ness)]     [he has <the property of> sick(ness)]

  "An pa dice de an anas es pato."*
[he did talk about his d. be(ing) sick(ness)]

An pa dice de an anas; qi habe pato. OR An pa dice de an anas; habe pato.
 
  Either of these 'feels' better than the sentences using ~es~.

>> His hat, which is red, is enormous.
>> An kefa-ve; qi habe rubi kolori, habe enormo metri.
>
>"An kefa tegu qod pa es melano nu es polio." -- whatever.
>
>QOD is ok, but KE is not? GMAFB.
>
*   It is obvious that we approach communication, and the language involved
in its achievment, from different directions.  The ''whatever'' example is
confusing: with usage, things go from whiteness to blackness, not the other
way around.  The functional location in which you placed the "qod", is that
of a Relative Pronoun - defined in Glosa as ~qi~.  So, the ~ke~, which
relates to verbs, not nouns, would not have been used in this situation.

    When Rick Morneau and I were both on Conlang, we did exchange ideas on
syntax, sometimes differing on points of usage: I will happily read his
recent release on the matter - when I find time.  Thank you for the URL.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

I've further refined the word selection "technology" ...
and thought of some objective measures to apply to results.

For instance, the combined official Glosa dictionaries
contain approximately 8468 unique G-words that yield
7906 unique English equivalents. However, this requires
12681 entries in total, which indicates the overlap
of the much-decried excess of synonyms in the GED.
Any manual word selection process tends to produce
this effect, but by algorithm I am getting more like
6318, 5743, 6318; in other words, much less overlap,
implying better coverage of semantic space.

Also, it appears that automatic handling of the
"false friends" problem is possible by use of a
clever/dirty heuristic trick. Inevitably there
will be troublesome entries like this:

farin  FLOUR    fre farine, ita farina, por farinha
farin  floury   ita farinaceo
farin  meal     fre farine, por farinha
farin  PHARYNX  eng pharynx, ita faringe, spa faringe

The current algorithm resolves this by selecting the
"farin = flour" possibility and forgetting "pharynx".
It also makes for a neater reverse-sorted listing,
and remaining synonyms are glaringly apparent:

Result    ENGLISH      Multilingual sources
--------  ===========  --------------------
fable     fable        eng fable, fre fable
fabul     fable        por fÃ¡bula, spa fÃ¡bula
fabric    fabricate    eng fabricate, fre fabriquer, ita fabbricare, por fabrique, spa fabricar
face      face         eng face, fre face
cara      face         por cara, spa cara
facet     facet        eng facet, fre facette, spa faceta
facial    facial       eng facial, spa facial
facil     facile       eng facile, fre facile, ita facile, por fÃ¡cil, spa fÃ¡cil
facsim    facsimile    eng facsimile, spa facsÃ­mil

I think using a better Italian dictionary could resolve
many of the ties, like cara/face and fable/fabul ...
but this is only intended as a proof-of-concept anyway.

Subject: Re: [glosalist] BNF?
From: Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au>

At 12:38 PM 5/7/02 -0700, Charles wrote - in reply to Sid's question:
>> please, what is BNF?
>
>Rick Morneau's essay is now at ...
>http://www.onewest.net/~ram/syntax.html
>
*  Yes Folks,
   I had a look at Rick's essay, and BNF is a computer technology way of
spelling out the syntax used in a computer programming language.
   Now, Rick is a great guy, but he writes in a rather dry style.  So,
should you check out this essay, be prepared to do quite a lot of hard
thinking ... some of it 'between the lines.'

   Although I am only half-way through it so far, I would venture a
progress report:-
  . Sorry, there is no ready explanation of what BNF stands for.   
  . The BNF system successively analyses sentence structure into its
smaller parts, so that the syntactic definition of a sentence might take
five, or more, lines (layers of ever-deeper analysis) to tease it out.
  . Rick does give examples, but leaves the reader to link the parts of the
example with the actual theory, as stated in the essay.
  . From the limited existing evidence of changes in the gross syntax of
languages, Rick says the conclusion is that languages fluctuate between SOV
and VSO order, with neither being the ultimate form; and he states very
clearly that the SVO expression of a language is considered to be a
transitional stage between these two 'polar' forms.  English and Glosa, it
seems, are both in 'transitional' mode. 
  . Quite clearly, he gives the word, "that" two distinct syntactic
function when it is operating in ''relative'' mode: in the normal one,
"that" is a 'relative pronoun' starting an Adjectival Clause modifying the
Noun, which it follows - usually immediately; and the less described "that"
he calls a Conjunction ('and', 'but', 'or' class) and shows that it
modifies the Verb, starting a Noun Clause when at the beginning of the
sentence, or an Adverbial Clause if it comes after the Verb it modifies.

   So, relating this to the subject of this List, Rick defines the two
syntactic function that the English "that" translates into, when the
''relative'' concept is used in Glosa:
    A. "The cow, that is in the milking shed, needs to be let out."
   In this example we have the normal ~qi~ usage with its controversial,
preceding ";" to indicate the start of an Adjectival Clause.
       ~U vaka; qi habe loka intra u mulge-do, nece gene lase ab.~

    B. "He ran so quickly that he arrived first."
       "She said, that we must walk slowly."
       "That it is going to rain, is quite clear from looking at the sky." 
   In these sentences, the "that," which Rick describes as a Conjunction,
relates directly to the action, and starts an Adverbial Clause or a Noun
Clause.  I suggest, that in his essay, Rick has clearly pin-pointed a valid
syntactic difference in the uses of "that" when it starts subordinate
clauses in English; and, I consider that such a difference also exists in
Glosa when employing the ''relative'' concept, and that the two forms ~qi~
and ~ke~(O.G.)
amply, and beneficially, embody this difference.
       ~An pa kursi ta celero, ke an veni prima.~   ------- a.
       ~Fe pa dice: ke na debi lento gresi.~    ----------- b.
   OR  ~Fe pa dice: na debi lento gresi.~    -------------- b'.    
       ~Ke il fu pluvi, habe fo evide ex u ciela.~   ------ c.
   OR  ~Ke il fu pluvi, na klari vide ex skope u ciela.~ -- c'. 

... to be continued, after I read the second half of Rick's gripping work.  

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell
  P.S.  It's an interesting essay: I suggest that all read it.  R.

*  Thanks for the support, Kevin,
   I was totally blown away by this part of Rick's essay, and will send an
extract from the essay to Wendy .. requesting that she reconsider her
earlier statement on the undesirability of ~ke~.
   Also, it really doesn't matter whether we use a colon, semi-colon, comma
or nothing ... when introducing supplementary clauses.  When the reader is
engrossed in the exploits of Cinerala, he/she is not going to stop reading
or become confused by the absence or over-use of punctuation, which is only
supposed to be an aid to humanisation of the text, simulating the
writer/speaker's pauses and intonation.
   Rather than worry about it, I would suggest that Glosa writers do, in
fact, use the punctuation of their choice, when writing stories, and
calling on this ''relative'' function.  This is similar to the suggestion
Ron Clark made, in relation to the 'terminal vowel': allowing it to
"float."  Needless to say, that "floating" of the vowel did cause a lot of
havoc, and gained little benefit; however, allowing the punctuation before
~qi~ and ~ke~ to 'float' should do far less damage, and might do some good.

   What really will do harm is if Glosa-pe do NOT write stories in Glosa -
whichever punctuation they might plan to use!!!

> extract from the essay to Wendy .. requesting that she reconsider her
> earlier statement on the undesirability of ~ke~.
>   Also, it really doesn't matter whether we use a colon, semi-colon, comma
> or nothing ... when introducing supplementary clauses.

There are languages that use only one particle for sub-clauses.
Europeans use "que" "quel" and "qui", Glosa lacks the "que":

QUE/THAT ..... "I know KE the world is flat."
QUI/WHO ...... "Columbus is the guy QI is wrong."
QUEL/WHICH ... "Round is the shape QOD is impossible."

I'd rather eject QI and QOD and keep KE, because easier:
"the guy KE is wrong", "the shape KE is impossible".
We can do that in English (THAT=KE) in most cases too,
though there are too many THATs altogether ... and often,
a THAT can be elided as in "I know the world is flat".

> This is similar to the suggestion
> Ron Clark made, in relation to the 'terminal vowel': allowing it to "float."

I think he was right to let it float.

Subject: [glosalist] dictionary of IAL roots
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Mon, 27 May 2002 20:04:08 -0700

I've been experimenting with word-selection algorithms,
now importing the Glosa and Ido vocabularies. They can
mix well with the Romance languages, unsurprisingly.
Glosa closely resembles Italian, as was suspected.
Anyway, here is an illustrative example, taking all
resulting NOV- items from the raw data, and assuming
the format to be obvious enough ...

nov    new        4  fre nouveau, ido nov, ita nuovo, por novo
nov    nine       2  ita nove, por nove
nov    nova       2  eng nova, spa nova
nov    novel      3  fre nouveau, ita nuovo, por novo
nov    tidings    2  glo nova, ita nuova
novam  again      2  ita nuovamente, por novamente
novel  novel      4  eng novel, glo noveli, por novela, spa novela
novel  novelette  2  eng novelette, ido novel
novel  novelist   2  eng novelist, spa novelista
novel  novelly    2  eng novelly, fre nouvel
novem  november   3  eng november, glo novembro, ido novembr
noven  ninety     2  por noventa, spa noventa
noven  novena     2  eng novena, spa novena
novic  novice     3  eng novice, fre novice, ido novic

First, there seem to be 7 distinct and useful meanings
among the lot, most of them overloading "nov" to the extent
that it cannot rationally serve as a root unaided. The trick
of using terminal vowels to differentiate them is inadequate.
This also happens with most other simple 3- or 4-letter roots.
I conclude that longer CVCVC roots are needed for the base
international vocabulary G's authors call "Mega-Glosa".

Second, there has been a great shift and development from
Greco-Latin to the modern languages; NOVEL today brings
to mind a lurid daytime tv series for housewives, a NOVA
is an exploding star, NOVEM is the 11th month (not 9th).
It would be worse to deny the modern meanings, confusing
99% of the potential audience for an IAL, than to select
totally new and arbitrary meanings, as did Loglan/Lojban.

Third, there is no way to prevent overlap of meanings.
NOVEL will usually mean "a long story", more or less,
but it will also mean "new and unusual", unless people
stretch NOVIC to mean both "someone new to something"
and "a thing that is new to the observer".

So, accepting the algorithm's choice of roots and merging
meanings for NOVEN and NOVIC and NOVEL, and allowing those
troublesome terminal vowels to just float away ...

novam = again
novel = novel, new
novem = november
noven = novena, nine
novic = novice, new

Of course I cheated on "nine", a notorious case.
Maybe adding a few more vocabs would resolve that.
I'm certainly non-accepting of NON = "nine" ...

glo  enea   nine
glo  nona   nine
ido  non    nine
fre  neuf   nine
ita  nove   nine
por  nove   nine
spa  nueve  nine

>> I'd rather eject QI and QOD and keep KE, because easier

> This is effectively what the Glosa authors are
> saying, except they chose ~qi~.

> (as in "the guy; QI is wrong",
> "the shape; QI is impossible")

It looks to me (but it's difficult to ascertain) they meant
QI to be animate and QOD inanimate, or else QI as nominative
and QOD objective. I think just one particle could cover all.
The authors clearly put the semicolon in the wrong position,
at the beginning of the sub-clause; which is already marked by
the relative particle. Sic! I suppose they want to distinguish
attributive from restrictive clauses, but why bother?

About the floating gender vowels ... English speakers don't
realize we have the same 2 grammatical genders as the French,
a feminine in -e and a masculine in -(null), e.g. bat/bate,
hat/hate, mat/mate, ad inf.

At 05:41 PM 5/22/02 -0700, Charles wrote:

>>[RG] I was totally blown away by this part of Rick's essay, and will
send an extract from the essay to Wendy .. requesting that she reconsider
her earlier statement on the undesirability of ~ke~.

>>   Also, it really doesn't matter whether we use a colon, semi-colon,
comma or nothing ... when introducing supplementary clauses.

>

>[C]  There are languages that use only one particle for sub-clauses.

>Europeans use "que" "quel" and "qui", Glosa lacks the "que":

>

*  I think that the languages , which restrict their 'clausal flag' to
one particle, are impoverishing themselves; also, I call to attention the
initial letter of the Euro 'clausal flag.'  Perhaps this suggests that
there is some semantic functionality in the alphabet: I have been working
on this assumption, for ages.


>QUE/THAT ..... "I know KE the world is flat."

>QUI/WHO ...... "Columbus is the guy QI is wrong."

>QUEL/WHICH ... "Round is the shape QOD is impossible."

>

>I'd rather eject QI and QOD and keep KE, because easier:

>"the guy KE is wrong", "the shape KE is impossible".

>We can do that in English (THAT=KE) in most cases too,

>though there are too many THATs altogether ... and often,

>a THAT can be elided as in "I know the world is flat".

>

*   Amazingly, I'd have picked Charles as one who would call for greater,
rather than less, discrimination in language.  However, I wish to add
that, as in English, these different 'clause markers' might introduce
different sorts of clauses, similarly - but not identically - I believe
them to have such a function in Glosa.

    My reading of the Glosa literature, both explanatary (in English),
and the corpus (in Glosa), leads me to shed the word-for-word translaion
idea for these particles: there is <bold>not</bold>, as Charles suggests
a

   QUE/THAT / KE 

   QUI/WHO / QI

   QUEL/WHICH / QOD

                         relationship.


   In English, many have trouble with the THAT and WHICH introducing
Adjectival Clauses, modifying Nouns.  There is little to discriminate
between them: it is tedious, but I will answer questions if
non-native-speakers-of-English ask; in this situation they have identical
syntactic function.

   Meanwhile, THAT in English, can be an Identifier, an Adjectival Clause
marker, and an Adverbial Clause marker: these usages all have different
syntactic funtions:-

    He wore THAT hat.        ................................Id.

    He wore the hat THAT is now hanging on the third peg. ...Adj.

    He wore the hat THAT way.      ..........................Adv.

    He wore it THAT all would know he was king.   ...........Adv.

    They all knew THAT he was king, because of the crown (THAT) he 
wore.

              ^   Adv.                               ^    Adj.

              |_ [..............]                    |__ [............]


   And WHO(M), THAT and WHICH, different though they might look, can all
have the same syntactic function ... of introducing an Adjectival Clause,
with of course, the WHO or WHOM introducing a clause that modifies a
personal Proper Noun, collective noun describing people, or a personal
pronoun.  This could all be shown to be so, using examples; however, to
return to Glosa, it seems that the one word, QI, introduces 

<bold>all </bold>Adjectival Clauses.

    An habe tri feli; qi fago mega qantita de sito.    [... WHICH ...]

    An es un andra; qi habe tri mega feli.             [... WHO ...]

    An habe u manu; qi pa don u fatali impakti.        [... THAT ...]

    An; qi holo vi ski, fu tosto ki ex ci.             [... WHOM ...]


  As I have said before, English is a "bastard language" having had not
one, but many, illegitemate fatherings.  Glosa, on the other hand, the
sole issue of Ron and Wendy, had the chance of getting a well-defined
pedigree.  Breeding such a 'pedigreed' language, the authors sought to
eliminate most of the ^mongrel^ elements of English and those of most
Euro-languages - to produce a language, in which the Synax was pure.


  So, we come to a divide: prior to Glosa, words were concrete things
whose meanings were solid object connected to the categories of things
they symbolised; crossing the 'Bridge of Abstraction,' Glosa moved into
the land, where words symbolised concepts; and the ordering of these
symbols determined which function the concept would manifest ...
<italic>thing, action </italic>or <italic>description. 

  </italic>Back from the somewhat Celtic, fairy-tale story, above,
becoming more grounded and materialistic, I would say that we need to see
the syntactic function, within Glosa, as of paramount importance.<italic>
 </italic>Still, being human, and hearing words in our heads .. as well
as 'feeling' ideas .. the Glosa syntactic abstractions need to be able to
be grounded in the more concrete national languages, that we have used as
thinking tools, heretofore.


  QI  =   Adjectival Clause flag [that ; which; who; whom]

  KE  =   Ad␀␀␀␀ial Clause flag  (of reason) [that; so]

  TE  =      "         "     "   (of intention) [in order to]

  LO  =      "         "     "   (of place) [where]  

  TEM =      "         "     "   (of time) [when]  

  KA  =      "         "     "   (of cause) [because]


   These are the Glosa particle that deal with most daily events, and I
would stress, again, that they are not related on a word-to-word basis
with National language words, but <bold>are </bold>related directly to
the syntactic/semantic function of the concepts conveyed.  In terms of
"Language Universals," the various Adverbial Clausic Markers will all
occur in the same position(s) in relation to the position of the verb, IE
they are positionally inter-replaceable .. because they all have the same
syntactic function.


>> This is similar to the suggestion

>> Ron Clark made, in relation to the 'terminal vowel': allowing it to
"float."

>

>I think he was right to let it float.

>

*   Can't recall my actual quote here, but, yes, and no: the floating of
the final vowel was a research ploy, not a final word on the language.

    Ron hoped that some pattern of "natural" use would emerge if he
encouraged "Glossa" users to allow intuition to aid them in the choice of
final vowels for the concept-words they used - noting that they were not
(necessarily) specific for different Parts of Speech.  The result of the
experiment could have had permanently 'floating' final vowels; some
vowels preferred for certain Parts of Speech; or a final decision, on the
final setting of terminal vowels for each word, determined on a
word-by-word basis.  Well, there has been a strong majority of
Glosalist-pe in favour of setting the final vowel for each word, such
that children might be taught the <bold>correct</bold> spelling for each
word .. with an unchanging final vowel.

    The GID is a step along the way for settling these finals.  With a
little more tweaking, the GID can be pushed to being a GD, such that for
most English words there was one Glosa word; with, for a small number of
words, a second Glosa word, representing the single synonym.


Saluta,


Robin Gaskell

At 10:41 AM 5/21/02 -0700, Charles wrote:
>Syd said:
>

>> simple souls who need a clear jargon-free syntax
>

*   I have tried 'parse trees' and as helpful as they might have seemed,
originally, I now tend to think that they could have been one of Chomsky's
mistakes.  They are so awkward and space-consuming, that the Chomsky brain
should have come up with 'parse bushes' or 'parse herbs' as a simplification.
    So, I will mention here that throughout history, some thinkers have
tried to symbolise the syntactic elements of sentences.  And, naturally
enough, simply because Glosa is a language with "Syntax-based Grammar," I
decided to have another look at the possibility of doing so.  (GAS is
attached)

 At noon, he ran across the road, which was very busy.

 _@ .  ' \!  @ .   (\! %>)_                 .............(GAS)

Tem midi, an pa kurso tran u via; qi pa habe fo aktivi.

 _@ .  ' \!  @ .   (\! %.)_                 .............(GAS)

  Note there is little between the syntactic codings for the English and
Glosa versions.
  While it does no harm to ^blow ones own trumpet^, so far, it has done no
good, either.  One day, I will publish the GAS system as a monograph;
anyone, who, after reading the attachment, is interested in helping refine
this syntactic analysis, and in adding their name to the author line,
should contact me.

>Your plea contains 2 subclauses, a fancy genitive,
>a free compound, and coordination sans conjunction,
>5 nouns 4 verbs 3 adjs 3 determs 2 preps 2 pronouns
>(but no adverbs of any variety, a great relief).
>
*  I suspect that the sort of analysis - resulting in a list of categories
- done by Charles is not very helpful.  By contrast, the GAS is economical
on space, and does maintain the locations of the words, phrases and clauses
symbolised .. using space(s) as part of the analysis.  Also, the GAS
provides both visual and literal dimensions to the analysis.

>The simple teenage souls are presently out evolving
>some sort of hyper-encoded acronymic chat language
>tailored to their text-messaging toys.
>
*  It is frightening to think that, via SMS, Chat and online-realtime
games, we might all be typing   thx  np  .
   Thanks, no problem.

   My daugher has an "Everquest" character at Level 40; if my characters
are to aspire to such success, I, to, will have to learn to interact
quickly with other player, saying such things as  
  RU OK   ROFL  :-(0) .
   Are you OK, (I am) rolling on the floor laughing (and) shouting.
   
Saluta afk

Subject: [glosalist] BNF?
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Wed, 29 May 2002 01:28:22 -0700

> I call to attention the initial letter of the Euro 'clausal flag.'
> Perhaps this suggests that there is some semantic functionality
> in the alphabet: I have been working on this assumption, for ages.

Romance langs botched it horribly by confusing the question words
with relatives (QUE QUI QUEL), but English did better distinguishing
its WH from TH words (WHAT vs. THAT). It is a well-known mistake in
IAL design to follow that Romantic error. Of course Rick Morneau has
addressed the use of TH deictic words, as we've discussed before.
The so-called "correlatives" of Esperanto are a good example.

>> I'd rather eject QI and QOD and keep KE, because easier

> Amazingly, I'd have picked Charles as one who would call for greater,
> rather than less, discrimination in language.

You underestimate my laziness. An easier IAL is a better one.

> it seems that the one word, QI, introduces <bold>all </bold>Adjectival Clauses.

Well, that would solve that. Let's jettison the useless and ugly QOD.
Still, KE would be nicer than QI, which looks more Chinese than Greek.
And why not fuhnetisaiz Q to KU, anyway?

> Glosa, on the other hand, the sole issue of Ron and Wendy,
> had the chance of getting a well-defined pedigree.

DNA testing reveals that QOD (and much besides) was Hogben's.

> Glosalist-pe in favour of setting the final vowel for each word, such
> that children might be taught the <bold>correct</bold> spelling for each
> word .. with an unchanging final vowel.

An IAL is for adults, not children. And adults in the real world will
never memorize arbitrary terminal vowels.

> the GID can be pushed to being a GD, such that for
> most English words there was one Glosa word; with, for a small number of
> words, a second Glosa word, representing the single synonym.

That would be horrible, but if you want to relex English it has been done
very systematically already in "Classical Yiklamu", somewhere on the web.
It comes with a nice grammar and appears to be complete, usable, and cute.

A lot has been learned about typography and easy legibility.
It's necessary to emphasize breaks between long sentences,
and the substructures within them.

So the first thing I'd do (besides breaking the long block into
smaller paragraphs) would be to either: 1) use the international
convention of starting all sentences with a capitalized word,
and this would be especially easy in Glosa because a capitalized
particle (like U) would not be mistaken for a proper noun;
and/or, 2) leave extra space between sentences, or even invent
a new bizarre bit of punctuation like "double-period" for what
most Europeans call the "full stop". Before and after:

> intra u mo kam eko mero ko u frigi plus no-juve aero,
> qi nu es no-facili de u spira, u andro, ge-vesti per u
> somni kam tegu vesti, qi pa es ge-denti ex plu poli
> poda zoa, nu sedi. pan proxi an, nu es plu skoria de
> plu ge-uti fumi ra e plu vasa, mero ge-vora flu. ante
> de an, nu es u lami stru ko plu zero dina gono e qi nu
> feno posi kade. an nu tenta trovi u loka pro u litera
> meka inter plu grega de plu meso-puri papira lami. an
> nu zero pote bali ab plu lami, kausa u skoria vasa pre
> nu habe sati e plus. e plus-co, inter plu zero
> ge-reakti nota e place, posi, nu es u konto domi nota
> de u valu de bi Guinea, proxi sura, an pa zero dona qi
> ad u konto domi. plus, an nu debi grafo ad intra an sa
> u bibli plu eko loka mini ra de plu mite pe de plu-ci
> nota. anti-co, u bibli nu es ge-lose, e u puta de u
> tenta trovi id (alo, veri de u tenta trovi plu hetero
> ra) nu sti u emotio turba ad an, seqe-co, an gene plu
> akuto pulsa de u sto bio de se.

Intra u mo kam eko mero ko u frigi plus no-juve aero, qi nu es
no-facili de u spira, u andro, ge-vesti per u somni kam tegu
vesti, qi pa es ge-denti ex plu poli poda zoa, nu sedi.

Pan proxi an, nu es plu skoria de plu ge-uti fumi ra e plu vasa,
mero ge-vora flu.  Ante de an, nu es u lami stru ko plu zero
dina gono e qi nu feno posi kade.

An nu tenta trovi u loka pro u litera meka inter plu grega
de plu meso-puri papira lami.  An nu zero pote bali ab plu lami,
kausa u skoria vasa pre nu habe sati e plus.

E plus-co, inter plu zero ge-reakti nota e place, posi, nu es
u konto domi nota de u valu de bi Guinea, proxi sura, an pa zero
dona qi ad u konto domi.  Plus, an nu debi grafo ad intra an sa
u bibli plu eko loka mini ra de plu mite pe de plu-ci nota.

Anti-co, u bibli nu es ge-lose, e u puta de u tenta trovi id
(alo, veri de u tenta trovi plu hetero ra) nu sti u emotio turba
ad an, seqe-co, an gene plu akuto pulsa de u sto bio de se.

..

As for the Glosa style, within each sentence I find it no-facil
for several reasons, mainly the fault is in Glosa itself, but
also the structure is too disjointed, like a typical idiomatic
run-on sentence in English, even adding commas doesn't help,
but a strict adherance to SVO + prepositional phrases would.
An auxlang should maximize the reader's comfort by using simple
standard patterns with a much higher frequency than would a
natlang. Especially one that relies so heavily on syntax.

I don't think the use of disconnected "ra" is legal in Glosa,
that's one of the special suffixes (all of which I dislike)
that need to be hyphened to their roots for clarity. BTW, if
Glosa used noun-adjective word order (as it probably should)
then the particles like U PLU etc would best hyphenate too.
One feels this especially when a line break intervenes.
Some people hate Glosa's hyphens, but I like them ...

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] (in-)definite article(s)
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Thu, 06 Jun 2002 23:56:51 -0700

For easy automatic relexing, short of true translation,
from English and many other significant languages,
we need to specify good equivalents for the English
numberless indefinite article "the", and for the so-called
demonstrative adjectives "this/that/these/those" --

Glosa lists U-CI U-LA PLU-CI PLU-LA for demonstratives,
and uses U or UN and PLU as *definite* articles.
It seems to me that U/UN/PLU make excellent *indefinite*
articles, while LA/CI better serve for the definite.

Consistently using UN instead of the unlovely U and
freeing the order of particles, it could be like:

UN FELI = a cat
PLU FELI = some cats

CI FELI = LA FELI = the cat(s)

CI UN FELI = UN CI FELI = this cat
LA UN FELI = UN LA FELI = that cat

CI PLU FELI = PLU CI FELI = these cats
LA PLU FELI = PLU LA FELI = those cats

Maybe CI FELI vs. LA FELI could express some nuance.
I don't know. It's just an idea.

Kevin wrote:

> I agree that U/UN/PLU seem more indefinite than definite.

> But UN, to me, is too close to UNO and "one". Perhaps we could drop U/UN
> altogether in favor of MO?

> Literally, "here cat", "there cat" (...everywhere a cat cat :-)

> I have thought about replacing U-CI with CI, but it just seemed like "here" was
> an important enough concept not to muddle up with "this", let alone "the".

My real intent was to get "LA = the" as in other euro-style IALs.
If that link were broken as in Loglan/Lojban, it would be easy to
define reasonable apriori particles. Then MO would be much better
than U/UN, which is indeed the same as "one" and English "a/an".
But as I understand it, the authors wanted Glosa to serve as an
introduction to Mega-Glosa, which imports all international words
much as the other euro-IALs do.

The same word could be used for "one" and "a", or "there" and "the",
provided the syntax supports it. All pidgins use phrases like
"one black cat finish eat there mouse", because that's the basis
for all language anyway ... But it does sound rather bizarre and
might not attract the sort of upscale market desired.

One good feature of Glosa is the ability to add or elide particles,
so it is not necessary but remains possible to specify tense, number,
and other such notions. Logically there ought to be an orthogonal
set including at least { singular, plural, definite, indefinite,
near, far, masculine, feminine, animate, inanimate }. These could
be freely applied at the start of any noun phrase (but after the
optional preposition). By eliding the remainder of the noun phrase,
we obtain "pronouns". So a mo' careful design is essential ...
Maybe we should collect and study Shaq talk.

noun-phrase := (preposition) (articles) (adjectives) (noun)
preposition := ad | de | etc.
article     := un | la | mi | etc.
adjective   := melano | blanco | etc.
noun        := feli | etc.

> But R gimn and G die hymne make anthem not-international word.

My super-non-authoritative database of true international words
has only "hymn = eng hymn, fre hymne, glo himna, ido himn, spa himno"
for this approximate concept, i.e. a special theme song. In other words,
3 major source languages (French Spanish English) and at least
2 well-known IALs (Ido Glosa) have selected this root.

Stretching HIMNA to cover both meanings is exactly what an IAL
would need to do, in order to cover the entire semantic space
with a reasonably small number of words. The only thing that
bothers me about it, is that H goes silent in most languages.

From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com

Not a lot of life in this group since Wendy reasserted
control over Glosa. Where there's hope, there's talk.

It was Otto Jesperson, the most famous linguist of his time,
who invented the International Phonetic Alphabet. Later,
he participated in the 1907 committee to reform Esperanto
which produced Ido. He served as its president for some years
until it became clear that Occidental was scooping up all of
Ido's followers in the 1920's. Then he tried to ameliorate
Occ's flaws with his own Novial, which eventually merged
back into it just before WW II (after which they both
devolved into Gode's Interlingua, another story ...).

Anyway, Jesperson left us a wonderful book which is
fortunately available for free on the web. And in it
he openly discusses many of the design choices faced by
any aspiring IAL creator/reformer. In particular I'm
now interested in his remarks on the letter Z at:

http://www.geocities.com/Athens/Forum/5037/AILz.html

In my own expriments in algorithmifying the selection
of international words from free online sources, I had to
deal with this troublesome letter (like J did) replacing
it with either S or C depending on its environment:

$word =~ s/([aeiou])z([aeiou])/${1}s${2}/g;
$word =~ s/z([aou])/s${1}/g;
$word =~ s/z/c/g;

I'm convinced that it needs to be removed from any viable IAL
because it is too confusing for the potential target audience.

Subject: [glosalist] A Question For The List
From: N0PSB{at}aol{dot}com
Date: Mon, 17 Jun 2002 09:08:50 EDT

Please pardon my not writing in Glosa, but I am not yet a Glosa-pe, and I am 
trying to gather information.

At the University of Richmond in the United States we have Bachelor's and 
Graduate degree programs in disaster science and emergency management.  As 
part of those programs we publish a free electronic journal that we wish to 
make available to an international audience.  We are considering auxiliary 
languages as one way of doing so, and plan to use Internacia Lingvo 
(Esperanto) in that effort because of the number of speakers and readers.  In 
examining the other auxiliary languages, Glosa appears to have the next most 
vibrant community.  

Can the list give me an idea of how many people use Glosa today, in how many 
countries, whether there is any scientific literature in Glosa, and whether 
the Glosa community would be receptive to such an effort?

Thank you for your help.

Walter G. Green III, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor of Emergency Management
University of Richmond

--- N0PSB{at}aol{dot}com wrote:
> Please pardon my not writing in Glosa, but I am not yet a Glosa-pe, and I am 
> trying to gather information.

No problem. Welcome to our community.

I had expected someone like Robin or Marcel to respond already, but I'll provide 
my own opinions in the meantime.

> We are considering auxiliary 
> languages as one way of doing so, and plan to use Internacia Lingvo 
> (Esperanto) in that effort because of the number of speakers and readers.  

That sounds great, and your choice of Esperanto makes perfect sense as your 
first IAL, given its relatively massive base of speakers.

> In examining the other auxiliary languages, Glosa appears to have the 
> next most vibrant community.  

That's exciting to hear. I don't understand why more IAL's don't have mailing 
lists, because it is very difficult for a language to thrive without one.

> Can the list give me an idea of how many people use Glosa today, in how many 
> countries, whether there is any scientific literature in Glosa, 

Unfortunately, I suspect the head count of Glosa speakers is still quite small. 
It seems to be most popular in the USA, Europe, Australasia, and Russia, and I 
understand there are a number of African Glosa speakers who do not have internet 
access. I am not aware of any significant bodies of scientific literature in 
Glosa.

> and whether the Glosa community would be receptive to such an effort?

I would imagine that the Glosa community as a whole would be very receptive and 
cooperative.

Saluta,

Kevin

> I did find some interesting holes in
> Glosa vocabulary - academic ranks being one of them.  "Auxi sko-pe" was as
> close as I could come to Assistant Professor, but could be translated
> Assistant Instructor (almost not a rank) or Assistant Pupil - and that would
> drive the professorial ranks crazy.

Not all words in a vocabulary can be listed, without running over
100,000 entries in the dictionary. Only the basic words are listed.
The rules for selection of "Mega-Glosa" words state that all of
the "international" words are included in Glosa. A quick check
turns up the following:

eng assist, fre assistez, ita assistere, por assistir, spa asistir
eng professor, fre professeur, ita professore, por professor

So, you would be justified in using "asisti profeso" or thereabouts.
Terminal vowels are euphonic but non-significant (unlike Esperanto).

Subject: [glosalist] international vocabulary
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 2002 12:00:40 -0700

Mega-Glosa includes all the international vocabulary,
but doesn't provide a list of those words. I'm trying
to find them, and not by digging through 50-year-old
retreads of the Thorndike list ... Here are some of
the results so far, a table of counts of roots/stems
that are common across the 11 selected languages --
I included French Italian Spanish Portuguese and 6 IALs.
English is used as the pivot language, because it's easy
(the true reason for so many debateable design decisions).


         total    GOOD    fair    poor
ALL      10258    2388    3182    4688
ila       6920    2184    2284    2429
spa       4547    1825    1612    1080
fre       3680    1783    1197     678
eng       6348    1740    1957    2635
por       3155    1598     809     700
glo       2749    1500     793     440 <---
ido       2311    1396     559     301
ita       2595    1301     635     503
occ       1431     838     365     201
lfn       1348     820     332     196
lfr        877     438     225     213


I have found a total of 10258 word-stems that resemble
the synsets of WordNet, mentioned previously. Of those,
2388 were found in 5 or more of the source languages
(and marked as "good" above), 4688 only in 2 langs
(and therefore not very international). Sample:


10  eng family, fre famille, glo famili, ido famili, ila familia,
    lfn familia, lfr familia, occ familie, por famÃ­lia, spa familia

4   eng famine, fre famine, glo famina, ido famin

7   eng famous, ila famose, ita famoso, lfn famos, occ famos, por famoso, spa famoso


Glosa with its reviled GED words did very well, Ido with
its smaller word list was quite similar. The two LF sources
and Occ's are quite small and did very poorly. Ila hit 67%
of all possible matches, though it also has the largest
number of bad matches (obsolete medical terms etc.)

Increasing the quality of the source lists would certainly
improve the output, but it looks like there are only around
7,000 true international root-stems, the rest being variants.

If anyone wishes to assist with data entry or correction,
it would be appreciated ... However, I cannot expand the list
of source langs to include Germanic or Slavic. The sources
for FISP are at wordgumbo.com, and are not extremely good,
but I developed heuristic filters to avoid false positives.

At 11:00 PM 6/10/02 +0400, Alex wrote:
>Saluta!
>>[ ] My super-non-authoritative database of true international words
>> has only "hymn = eng hymn, fre hymne, glo himna, ido himn, spa >>himno"
for this approximate concept, i.e. a special theme song. In >>other words,
3 major source languages (French Spanish English) and at >>least 2
well-known IALs (Ido Glosa) have selected this root.
>Controll langs - German and Russian use it too.
>I just said that we can't say "Glosa's hymn", because this word is not
>used in this meaning in literary English (all the dics say
>so)! While R and G use it completely for both meanings!
>> Stretching HIMNA to cover both meanings is exactly what an IAL
>> would need to do, in order to cover the entire semantic space
>> with a reasonably small number of words. The only thing that
>> bothers me about it, is that H goes silent in most languages.
>Replace it by "G" - this the way used in Russian...
>
* This sounds like ~himna~ would become ~gymna~.
  However, I agree that the very religious symbol of a "hymn" may not be
suitable for something as all-encompassing as a Global Auxilliary Language.
 So, I looked up "ode" in the Latin dictionary, and found that:-
        ode(Eng)  =  carmen(Lat)
My guess is that using such a 'neutral' concept as thi would not detract
from the status of Glosa, but would avoid any pseudo-religiosity in
relation to a possible global medium of communication.
  I know that Esperanto has a 'Hymn,' but this is no reason for us - one
century later - to make the same mistake.

  While ~karmen~ is not in the Glosa lexicon, it quite well could be. 

Saluta,
Robin Gaskell

>Maybe all British-speakers front their vowels like Swedes,

>Now, why not generate sound directly from the writing,
>a soundex-type program (like the ancient Atari-800 used,
>to pronounce English text most amusingly)? There must be
>something out there on the net. Simulate nubile females
>or Darth Vaders speaking whatever ...

*  I have tried Dragon Dictate (Australian Version) and it worked very
well, but this costs about $A350, and doesn't allow a general 'Listen Only'
mode.  Needless to say, I was talking in English (possibly Australian); my
guess is that, for Glosa, a Dragon Dictate for Italian speakers would be
better than the English language version.

   In the ancient days of DOS 3, I did try a program that converted typing
into sound, but to get many of the Glosa vowel sounds, I had to spell the
words very funnily.

  Possibly there is a Public Domain, Italianate type-to-sound program out
there; in theory, Glosa has been designed to have only one pronunciation
for each letter, so the production of a _Glosa Pronunciation_ program
should not be all that difficult.  However, it sounds as if
English-speakers have lost the plot on truly international pronunciation of
vowels; so, such development work should be done by Europeans - preferably
not Swedes.

Mi du ergo epi u verba lista; pro na u mal-acide inter-reti loka.  Mi vo 
apreci plu vi komenta.   

task force - a tactical unit composed of several resource types
buta dina - u acide akti seri unita komposi de plu dura fonta tipo
(note - acide akti seri seems to me to be a good equivalent of tactics, see 
polisi akti seri for strategy below)

strategy - a planned course of action and allocation of resources to control 
a disaster at the community, state, or national level
polisi akti seri - u skema acti seri e u dura fonta asigna governa u 
mal-acide; ex u komunita alo stato alo natio

company - a fire or rescue unit composed of personnel and an emergency 
vehicle
kompani - u piro alo salva unita komposi de plu persona e u urge vagona 

battalion - an operational level of organization above the company in the 
fire service
multi kompani - u funktio organismo libela supra u kompani; in u piro service

Saluta,

Walter Green

*Hello Alain,
   Welcome  OR  Bene-veni.

   To get started in Glosa, you will probably need to acquire a wordlist,
and these are available on the Net.  The alternative is to buy  a copy of
_Glosa 6000_ through Wendy Asby, one of the authorswof Glosa:-
  Wendy Ashby 
  Glosa Education Organisation
  PO Box 18
  Richmond
  Surry TW9 2GE
  England

   Oh, yes; Please subscribe yourself to the Glosalist Mailing List if you
have not already done so - send a blank email:-

  To subscribe, e-mail: glosalist-subscribe{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au

  One place to start is the Glosa section of my website:-
     http://www.zeta.org.au/~rgaskell

  The language is in full working order, and there are numerous wordlists
available on various websites.  Owing to some haste at the beginning, some
variations of spelling do exist.  These have mostly been sorted out through
the GID (Glosa Internet Dictionary) Project.

  I did locate table of Glosa grammar on my website, but the most direct
place to start with understanding the Syntax-based Grammar is probably with
Seminars #1 & #2.
  Ron Clark, the prime author of Glosa, now deceased, did not want to write
a Glosa Grammar book, but prefered people to pick up the pattern by
observation - reading the periodical Plu Glosa Verba.  The primary rule is
that one word affects the next ... and so on.  The phrase is the basic unit
of Glosa, and these phrases are either Verb Phrases or Noun Phrases, with
the major word last in the phrase: this is described Linguistically as
'Head Final' structure.  The second major feature of Glosa is that a word
does not change morphologically for reasons of grammar. As in English,
where we have "to run" and "a run," similarly, in Glosa, the phrase
structure and surrounding words clarify gramatical function: the words are
not inflected.  As Ron Clark used to say, In Glosa a word can function,
within reason, as any part of speech.

  The Phrase and Clause structure is basically similar to that of good
English, and so, punctuation within sentences acts as 'signposts' to
indicate the start of new phrases and clauses - where an absence of such
marks might cause ambiguity.  I forgot to mention: we use
Subject-Verb-Object structure within sentences.
  There are two classes of words, the smaller group of 'function words'
(conjunctions, preposition, and determinants - in English), and the vast
body of words for things and action, called 'substantives' in Glosa.
  If you are interested in the possibility of using Glosa as an auxilliary
language, I would suggst that you start soon to put words togeter to form
simple sentences: say them out aloud, and consider whether they have a
pleasant sound, and whether you can recall your originally intended meaning
as you hear yourself speak your sentence.
A sentence that fails the hearing/sense test should probably be recast ..
until it feels right.  And finally, the quickest way to developing fluency
in Glosa is to reach the stage where you can 'think in Glosa' - at first,
in small sentences, of course.

  I trust that you find the language worthwhile.  One place to start would
be to 'retell' well-known French children's stories in Glosa.  I say
'retell,' rather than 'translate,' because, at the beginning you will be
restricted by a limited vocabulary, and might have to change the story
slightly to fit in with the Glosa vocabulary you know.

  We look forward to seeing you on the List.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

> For my part - trying to get pictures, spoken word and text together - I
> have been advised that "Flash" best creates Java-Script code capable of
> playing on most operating systems

No, that would be most non-standard and uninclusive.
Pure HTML (without javascript) and MPEG files are the way.
And the place for them is the web, never email lists ...

> If I knew what ^fronting my vowels^ meant, I might try to ^back^ them a bit.

The back vowels are the "U" and "O" sounds, so important in X-rated MPEGs.
They need to be pronounced with the lips rounded. British and even
Americans tend to disgrace these vowels, but the Scots avoided the
Great Sound Shift and so are more intelligible to continentals.
The sound of "A" is not so troublesome because it's understandable
whether fronted or not -- except when slurred into a schwa.
The only real antidote to English vowels is to live with Spanish
speakers several years, at least in my case. I gratuitously mention,
the RP posh "EU" diphthong is a sickening travesty of a solid "O".

> English-speakers have lost the plot on truly international pronunciation of
> vowels; so, such development work should be done by Europeans

I prefer Latin Americans, more musical and always rhotic.
But the letter "H" is a hopeless lost cause, always silent.

Hello Robin

I am happy to get in touch again with Glosa. I've got all issues of PGN and
all the books of Ron and Wendy. A year before Ron died, he said he was going
to work at a grammar for Glosa, but perhaps he changed his mind, or the dead
did not allow him to do that.

I like very much Glosa, but am not fully happy with some little things.
First of all, the important role of context to clarify the sense of words
introduces, in my opinion, some ambiguity. Secondly, there is some lack of
accuracy in the spelling of words, that changes according with issues of PGN
(I noticed the GID project). Thirdly, it seems to be no rule to decide if a
word coming from Latin will end with A or O or I (to be true, Ron wrote
about it in an old PGN, but some blur remains).

I've given those problems a great deal of thought, and it seems to me that
just some little changes to Glosa would fix it. I'd like to talk about it
with Wendy, but she presently has no e-mail address. If you like, I'll tell
you those ideas, but I've no intention to dictate anything.

Regards, Alain

Alain:

> the important role of context to clarify the sense of words
> introduces, in my opinion, some ambiguity

Syd:

> a long long time ago, I complained that the absence, so called, of grammar
> made some Glosa difficult to understand and was told that context always
> makes things clear. It doesn't. We need to have a clear grammar that is
> independant of meaning. I've been burbling on and experimenting that way
> for some time ........

I am happy to see a new critic has arrived. Through such
efforts Glosa may someday evolve into a great IAL. But I
think there is sufficient meta-grammar already in Glosa
to answer these questions: One simply adds more words
until the meaning is unambiguous. It is a huge advantage
of Glosa over Ido and Novial that over-fussy distinctions
are optional, never mandatory, e.g.,

kaval medik = horse doctor = doctor to/for horses
kaval milit = horse soldier = soldier with/on horse

In some weird situation a "horse doctor" might mean
"the doctor with a horse" but that isn't fatal, or
even a defect in the language -- we can simply say
"medik kon kaval" or whatever to get precise enough.
(I drop useless terminal vowels and ugly -PE suffixes,
because those are some of _my_ reform issues, but
at least I changed Cs into Ks, this time.)

As long as some kind of verbal phrase introductory particle
is always used, and similarly for the accusative/object,
and if relative clauses and punctuation are corrected,
Glosa's grammar is just fine! I'd change out most of the
particles though, like FU -> VA, PA -> FE, ...

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] A Contrarian View on Grammar
From: N0PSB{at}aol{dot}com
Date: Thu, 27 Jun 2002 09:40:22 EDT

I am a new Glossa user.  I am also not a gramatika-pe.  Based on my 
experience with Internacia Lingvo (Esperanto) and my review of at least a 
dozen other constructed languages, I think Glosa looses its distinctiveness 
and value in direct proportion to any increase in the size and complexity of 
its grammar.  Most of these efforts, except probably Unish, seem to focus on 
just how complicated a set of grammar rules they can construct to make 
language simpler.  Esperanto sells itself on how simple it is - my Esperanto 
introductory grammar book has 214 pages of grammar in it.

For someone who has not thought about grammar in 30 plus years the eight page 
(on my printer) Syntax-Based Grammar of Glosa was a challenge to get through. 
 I do not think I have mastered all of it yet - and I had to buy a grammar 
book just to understand what I was trying to understand.  If Glosa moves from 
that level of complexity to something approaching that of Esperanto, I have 
to ask, why not just give it up and learn Esperanto?

>From my perspective as a new user the distinctiveness of Glosa is (1) simple 
grammar that relies on word position to tell the story and (2) a simple, 
limited vocabulary.  These are also its great strengths as an auxiliary 
language - simple rules, plus not a thick dictionary to memorize (I am now 
approaching a foot long section of Esperanto dictionaries in my reference 
book case).

I have been working on translating a short technical paper on emergency 
response plans into Glosa - hence my proposed definitions posted on the 
listserv.  What is very obvious to me, again as a new user, is that the 
dictionary needs work, and a lot of it, to define clearly what the real 
English equivalents (and French and German and ...) are for given words. 

For example, I suggested polisi-akti-seri as an equivalent to the English 
word strategy (and, yes, I know it is bad Glosa to hyphenate three words 
together, but why?).  The GID has a Glosa word "strategi," which Nick 
suggested, along with some quite useful refinements of the definition - the 
GID defines this as "trick."  Those of us who work in the strategic 
environment identify strategy as the operationalization of policy into a 
course of action to achieve top level goals.  What is strategy and strategi 
to be - a policy level activity that guides the affairs of nations and 
organizations, or a simple trick to fool someone?  Or is it to be both, based 
on context?  Or do we go back to the root word context of strategy?

I think the real area of ambiguity in Glosa is the 1000/6000/GID.  This is 
not a criticism of any of these - they are tremendous efforts, especially the 
GID, and the authors deserve all of the credit in the world.  But if I, or 
any other author, am to write technical or scientific material, I need a 
better product to work from.  

The other comment I have is that Glosa's simple rules have had an interesting 
impact on how I think about my writing.  I find myself thinking more about 
what is important in what I am saying and a lot more about the relationship 
of words.

So my vote is do not fool with the grammar until we know what the words mean. 
 I am sure that the users of the list already understand the full meaning of 
the words, but until they are also obvious to new users I am not sure you 
will have achieved a solid foundation for growth.
      
Walter G. Green III, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor of Emergency Management
University of Richmond
wgreen{at}richmond{dot}edu
(804) 287-1246

Subject: Re: [glosalist] A Contrarian View on Grammar
From: "Alain Vezes" <alain.vezes{at}wanadoo{dot}fr>

In my opinion, Grammar is just a name for the set of rules for a language.
So, using the word "grammar" does not imply that this grammar is huge and
abstruse (a good Glosa grammar could comprise just about ten pages). But the
main goal is, as for words, there is no ambiguity. A good balance should be
found between simplicity and speed (but ambiguity) and accuracy (but
complexity).

> I am a new Glossa user.  I am also not a gramatika-pe.

I've been into Glosa and Interglossa since 1970.
Interlinguistics (study and design of bridge languages)
led me to study "real" linguistics. What is commonly
called "grammar" of the type taught in lower schools
(verbs, indirect objects, ad nauseum) is now at least
100 years obsolete. That is the sort of thing we can
do without in Glosa. But we can't contravene the
linguistic realities ...

> I think Glosa looses its distinctiveness and value
> in direct proportion to any increase in the size
> and complexity of its grammar.

Agreed. The designers/authors aimed Glosa at people
who basically hate "grammar", and this is correct
"strategy" for a bridge language, which will always
be a second language, learned and used by adults
for practical purposes. The model should be Swahili
(simplified Bantu with Arabic loanwords) or the
Lingua Franca (ultra-simplified Romance). All such
languages share many features, and not following
"grammarians" is one of those features ...

> Syntax-Based Grammar of Glosa was a challenge to get through.

Glosa's grammar is just a simplified mixture of English and
whatever Romance language one has studied in high school.
All inflections are eliminated, and word order within a phrase
is like English, modifiers preceding the words they modify.
There are around 50 special words called particles which do
whatever additional magic stuff which may be necessary.

> I had to buy a grammar book just to understand what I was
> trying to understand.

Just do a web search for "pidgins and creoles and Bickerton".

> why not just give it up and learn Esperanto?

I like all the artificial languages, but only a pidgin-like
analytic-grammar type such as Glosa or Lingua Franca can be
learned easily enough by the vast majority of working adults.
Others are nice toys or hobbies or secret-codes or cult langs.
However: Glosa leaves you with the problem of how to create
long compound words to simulate the huge vocabulary of concepts
an adult would need to use in the real world; this is the
problem of "derivation". The solution is to realize that
1000 basic roots get us nowhere. We need to import many more
from the already-existing "international vocabulary".
This was called "Mega-Glosa" by the authors.

> simple rules, plus not a thick dictionary to memorize

The trick is to use only those words that are already present
in the source (lexifier) languages. That is the Norman and
Latinate portion of English, as opposed to the Anglo-Saxon.
There's the winning "strategy" (French stratÃ©gie, Spanish
estrategia, Italian strategÃ¬a, etc). You know most of them
at-sight without any study, and once comfortable with the
system, you can guess most of the remainder. No pain.

> What is very obvious to me, again as a new user, is that the
> dictionary needs work, and a lot of it, to define clearly what the real
> English equivalents (and French and German and ...) are for given words.

I'm a programmer. I've written software to input public domain
bilingual word lists and cross-correlate them to find cognate words
with similar meaning. It generates approx 10,000 entries like this,
among which one can find the international words:

SORTKEY  BEST MATCH    MULTILINGUAL SOURCES ..................... ENGLISH SYNONYMS
strab    crosseyed     2  glo strabo, ila strabe                  1  crosseyed
strabis  strabismus    2  eng strabismus, ila strabismo           1  strabismus
strabot  strabotomy    2  eng strabotomy, ila strabotomia         1  strabotomy
strad    street        3  ido strad, lfn strada, occ strade       2  road street
stram    litter        2  glo strama, ita strame                  1  litter
stran    peculiar      2  ita strano, lfn strana                  2  peculiar strange
strang   strangle      3  glo strangula, ido strangul, ila stran  5  foreign odd strange strangle
straps   straps        2  eng straps, fre straps                  1  straps
strat    layer         4  glo stratu, ido strat, ila strato, ita  3  layer stratum street
stratag  stratagem     2  eng stratagem, ila stratagema           1  stratagem
strateg  strategy      4  eng strategy, fre stratÃ©gie, ido strat  1  strategy
stratif  stratify      2  eng stratify, ila stratificar           1  stratify
stratos  stratosphere  3  eng stratosphere, fre stratosphÃ¨re, il  1  stratosphere

> I know it is bad Glosa to hyphenate three words together, but why?

It's only bad if there is no shorter equivalent. Works fine in German ...

> a policy level activity that guides the affairs of nations and
> organizations, or a simple trick to fool someone?

The bad news is that all languages must work in exactly that way.
You have reified (and refined) the lowly word into a high concept,
but the word remains as it was, a mere culturally-founded artifact.
Above, the stated goal was minimization of vocabulary, but just in
computer jargon I could use up 10,000 specifically essential words,
so we're going to be hyphenating an awful lot, or else using more
general senses. Precision is impossible in the base vocabulary,
lower-frequency specific senses are implemented as compounds.

> I am sure that the users of the list already understand
> the full meaning of the words,

Not so!
