> Why does glosa have "q" - "ku" is the same sound, yes?

Many IALs have attempted to accommodate speakers pronouncing
"kw" as "kv". I think it would be much better to simplify,
and use only "ku". But then, as in Novial, the dictionary
gets eye-glazingly thick in the K section ...

But it is possible and desireable to eliminate spelling
difficulties, recognizing that each native speaker group has
different problems. By accepting the hard/soft C/G rule,
quasi-instinctive (by childhood training) to almost every
person in Europe/Americas/Australia, it is possible to
eliminate H J K Q W X Y Z, like a more-regularized Spanish.

It would gain immensely in both recognition and production.
Mangling the international vocabulary by strange spellings
(Esperanto, Ido, Novial, Glosa) is worse than semi-apriori
(Loglan/Lojban) because it's actually anti-mnemonic. Using
more natural spelling facilitates learning, for everyone.

And then Glosa could be marketed worldwide as a first step to
otherwise impossibly difficult (western) European languages.

>> Many IALs have attempted to accommodate speakers pronouncing
>> "kw" as "kv".

> Is that a good reason for spell [...] illogically?
> People shoudl learn to say it (the sounds) properly.

Ido tries to be "logical" but it is impossible to use.
Always remember that an IAL is a second language for adults,
and if it is too difficult they can't learn it. We must
accommodate a range of pronunciations in the real world,
not excluding people because of insignificant differences.

> (what's "ing" in glosa?)

English "-ing" is similar to Glosa "du-".

> The hard/soft rule is not is not the same throughout
> the european language lands.

We must use what is natural to Spanish/English/French,
the vast majority of all potential Glosa speakers.
It would be nice to include a wider audience, but that
is not possible. Unless you try Occidental instead.

>> Mangling the international vocabulary by strange spellings
>> (Esperanto, Ido, Novial, Glosa) is worse than semi-apriori

> It isn't! It's logic!

You can't win that argument. See the Ido vocabulary for
examples. Nobody can memorize all the artificial divergences.
So it can never be spoken or understood in real life, and
is hard enough even in writing, where you must look up
every word in a dictionary. Logically you could better use
numbers instead of words, with decimal points to mark off
the affixes.

>>  Using more natural spelling facilitates learning, for everyone.

> Well, but why not use simple Latin in that case?

Latin is not simple, and is dead. Whereas half the world today
speaks English/Spanish/French/Portuguese, and they all mix well.
So those are the best sources for vocabulary, and spelling must
be similar to Spanish. Logic! Just don't go changing random
letters to differentiate meanings, because that sort of mangling
destroys any potential ease of learning.

> But glosa isn't like those tongues. The grammar is very different.

Only superficially.

pronunciation, and that it was not necessary that
every sound should have only one spelling.

I haven't read Nick's Glo translation yet (the one he posted a few weeks ago). 
Here is my own. Note that this is written in Glo, not Glosa. I think that 
Glosa-pe can simply:
- Pretend each sentence starts with a capital letter
- Ignore 'ca', which begins a verb (or pretend it is 'nu')
- Ignore 'sa', which indicates posession
- Remember that 'zero' is used in place of 'ne'

I think it's a bit weak in a couple spots, due to Glo's very small (and 
unfinished) vocabulary. Still, I think it proves that 500 roots can go pretty 
far.

Now I'll go take a look at Nick's submission to see how close we ended up.

Kevin

pote vasa u an sa litera meka. u kam ca 
habe plu poli fini mero de plu pusi fumi 
pali, e ca habe plu vora flu vasa qi ca 
mero vasa. plu zero taxo e zero puri grega 
de papira lami ca es pan loka de an sa 
zero solida lami stru.

an ca zero debe bali ab plu la papira lami, 
kausa u skoria vasa ca es sati. plus, an 
ca doxo; ke an pa lose u bi Guinea 
valuta nota intra plu papira lami. plu ci 
papira lami ca habe plu poli zero ge-reakti 
grafo nota e plu zero ge-reakti vendo 
volu valuta nota. plus, plu grafo nota ca 
habe plu loka info, qi an ca debe grafo 
intra an sa loka info bibli.

mali fortuna, an pa lose an sa loka info 
bibli. u puta de tenta trovi u ra intra 
u kam ca kausa; ke an ca puta de sto an 
se sa bio.

From: Kevin Smith <kevins{at}qualitycode{dot}com>

--- N0PSB{at}aol{dot}com wrote:
> I am a new Glossa user.  I am also not a gramatika-pe.  Based on my 
> experience with Internacia Lingvo (Esperanto) and my review of at least a 
> dozen other constructed languages, I think Glosa looses its distinctiveness 
> and value in direct proportion to any increase in the size and complexity of 
> its grammar.  

I think there's a big distinction between Glosa's allowed grammar, and Glosa's 
documented grammar. (Or syntax--I'm not a linguist and don't know the right 
terms for these things). Anyway, Glosa currently allows a fairly wide and 
complex range of grammar elements. Personally, I think the language becomes much 
simpler if you have fewer (but stricter) rules. For those of us who speak 
English, Glosa syntax seems very natural, but for native speakers of other 
languages I'm not so sure. I would like to see a documented, and simplified, 
Glosa syntax.

> >From my perspective as a new user the distinctiveness of Glosa is (1) simple 

> grammar that relies on word position to tell the story and (2) a simple, 
> limited vocabulary.  

I agree with #1, although I would say the main distinctiveness is the complete 
lack of inflections. I agree with #2 if we constrain ourselves to roughly G1000, 
but many folks here believe Glosa needs more than 5000 roots to be viable. I 
would add a #3 which is Glosa's extensive use of Greek roots (for better or 
worse).

> listserv.  What is very obvious to me, again as a new user, is that the 
> dictionary needs work, and a lot of it, to define clearly what the real 
> English equivalents (and French and German and ...) are for given words. 

Agreed. I put in a lot of hours on an alternative Glosa core word list, and I 
tried to make the English definitions far less ambiguous. It certainly has some 
errors, is definitely not official, and has not been updated for some months 
because I have turned my attention to 'Glo' (a smaller, simpler version of 
Glosa). If you haven't already looked at my Glosa word lists, you might find 
them helpful:
  http://www.qualitycode.com/glosa
  http://www.qualitycode.com/glosa/glosaenglish-abc.html

> The other comment I have is that Glosa's simple rules have had an interesting 

> impact on how I think about my writing.  I find myself thinking more about 
> what is important in what I am saying and a lot more about the relationship 
> of words.

Strong agreement.

Kevin

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] what's the G word for ... random
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Tue, 02 Jul 2002 11:08:03 -0700

Officially, "elekti ali-ra". I suppose that could become
"elektalira" in theoretical usage. The authors apparently
found that sufficient. My incomplete database of other
languages lists the following translations of RANDOM:

fre  accidentel
por  acidental
ila  aleatori
spa  aleatorio
glo  elektialira
ila  fortuite
por  fortuito
occ  hasarde

The etymology of randomness began with the French
"randir=gallop" and "randon=speedy". Then some
random American computer programmers got hold of it.

The general issue is interesting, and yet another
ill-defined problem in Glosa: What's the correct
method for finding specific vocabulary? Especially
when the desired concept is not in the tiny sample
vocabularies provided. As a programmer I prefer
clear principles and test-able, working prototypes.
Anyone can invent words or even an entire language;
lacking either agreed principles or an authoritative
guide, nobody can use it to communicate effectively.

At first I supported use of the Glosa "core" list,
approx 1800 items altogether. It is essentially
a-priori, because nobody studies Greek anymore.
But it's completely inadequate for practical use.
Then we investigated the GID, and most of us reacted
unfavorably. If we have to learn all those Latin
words then Glosa isn't much different from the other
western-european-based auxlangs. I've compared the
entire Ido vs. Glosa vocabularies, they are nearly
identical ... same size, same coverage, same roots.

As I understand it, Glosa also includes the entire
"scientific vocabulary". That would be the so-called
"combining forms" such as ORNITHO and LOGY etc.
I've counted 700 of them, there may be 1000 or so,
still not enough to form a complete or usable vocab.

Mega-Glosa also includes "international vocabulary",
defined somewhere as those words common to several
European languages. Most other IALs have similar
selection rules, such as "English, French, and either
Spanish/Portuguese or German". By that standard,
"ALEA" is already a bonafide Glosa word. But until
it appears in official word lists, nobody realizes.

My own program found these for RANDOM: ACSID, ALEAT,
and FORTUIT. But in correspondence I'd say RANDOM,
anyway. It's a new, emerging international standard.
I'll bet Esperantists use it already, they have no
aversion to breaking or ignoring rules, they just
won't change them ...

<BR>
English "Aleatory" - Literally, depending on the throw<BR>
of the dice; hence, depending on a contingent event.<BR>
<BR>
>From Latin "aleator" dice-player, from "alea"<BR>
dice-game.</BLOCKQUOTE><BR>
a distinct possibility - describes what I want neatly<BR>

To: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] Glosa suffixes, the so-called "generics"
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Sun, 07 Jul 2002 12:47:53 -0700

The best thing about Glosa is lack of affixes.
We can almost say that Glosa has no morphology.
But the presence of "generics" spoils the plan:

SUFFIX  meaning(s)       full source
======  ==========       ===========
-BO     shop             BOteka
-DO     house, building  DOmi
-FA     set, bundle      FAski
-FI     filament         FIlament
-KA     room             KAmera
-LI     stone            LIto
-LO     place            LOka
-MA     material         MAteria
-ME     device           MEkani
-MO     furniture        MObili
-PE     person           PErsona
-RA     thing            ReAli
-RU     instrument       instRUmenta
-TE     cloth            TExtili
-VA     vessel           VAsa
-VE     garment          VEsti
-ZO     ring             ZOna

These are non-intuitive and anti-mnemonic,
and would be unrecognizeable in speech.
It is more efficient to use the full word
hyphenated, as with LECT(O)-ABILI etc.
In most cases the ending can be elided but
it remains available for use when needed.

Glosa should remain true to its own nature:
less fussy grammar, more practical logic.

No, and I don't think the public could ever accept them either.
Firstly because they are artificial, unattested in any language.
Secondly because they are too short, are not stressed, and so
cannot work (be recognized) in any ordinary speech environment.
Thirdly because they are completely un-mnemonic, therefore difficult.
Other than that, no problem ... except they're ugly, too.

> Innovation can be good.

But not in a bridge language (IAL). And I trust the innovative powers
of a billion persons working over 2000 years more than that of 1 or 10
people, even trained and famous linguists, putting together something
like Esperanto or Glosa etc. So I'm in the radical naturalist camp ...

> I believe written communication is much more important for an IAL than spoken. I
> think Glosa has some bigger problems than this in the spoken department. What do
> you mean by "not stressed"?

Well, yes to that. ... I imagine "Glosa-pe" pronounced with primary stress
on the first syllable and a secondary stress on the third. It seems to me
that in a language that is not used constantly in everyday life, the -PE
will not be sufficiently recognizeable, therefore cannot survive. Better
to use a real word like "-person" to compound it, instead of any affix.

> I haven't really thought about 'lo', but it seems
> like 'loka' is short enough not to need a shorter version.

Right -- and I think we can use bi-syllabic words for all root concepts,
which reduces the temptation to change INSTRUMENT to -RU; I think -METER
is a better choice than -RU. And then we aren't restricted to just 20
productive affixes, we have hundreds of potential compounders. The true
spirit of Glosa is to allow any word to serve any grammatical function,
"within reason" ... That idea is beginning to appeal to me more now.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] Suffixes As An Issue
From: N0PSB{at}aol{dot}com
Date: Mon, 8 Jul 2002 09:27:37 EDT

This listserv is quite helpful in clarifying for me key issues about Glosa.  
But much of the conversation raises a vital issue - who has the authority to 
change the language?

As long as Glosa is a hobby activity for a few people, it is reasonable for a 
half dozen people on a listserv to continually modify it - to decide they 
like or don't like suffixes, for example.  In the month or less I have been 
watching the mail, I would say there have been at least a dozen modifications 
suggested, some single words, some grammar rules, some definitions, and at 
least one derivative language.

If Glosa is to be more than a hobby, I would suggest the language must do two 
things:

(1) remain stable enough so that new users can learn it, and

(2) have some accepted way to develop and incorporate changes, so that those 
changes can be disseminated to the users.

The argument of course is that all languages are living things that change 
and evolve on a daily basis.  True enough.  But the languages that do so are 
large enough that certain pressures, either formal, as in national language 
academies, or informal, through general acceptance by large bodies of people 
who use them every day in a contiguous area, limit the excursions.  Even 
though use and vocabulary may change I can easily understand a passage 
written in English 20 years ago, 100 years ago, or 200 years ago.

If what I write today (and I just finished using the term mini-ra and 
grafo-pe in a paper) is to be understandable to a Glosa reader in 20 years, 
stability is not a bad thing. 

Let me suggest an extreme scenario - we on the listserv decide tomorrow that 
the clause and phrase structure makes no sense.  Instead, the verb should go 
first in every sentence, "plu" and "u" disappear (they are a real pain to 
remember to put in), and nouns should be written in all capitals, placed in 
the order of their importance to the thought, and followed by their 
modifiers.  How do we make that happen?  Do we simply post it on a new page 
on glosa.org, do I put it on my web page and it is official or unofficial, do 
we ask Wendy's permission (and if we do it, who takes responsibility for 
modifying all of the existing material stock of the Education Organization), 
or do we just start writing that way?

The impact of each of us on the language is potentially significant.  I asked 
a question about "strategy" - everyone agreed that "strategi" really means 
strategy, including Wendy, and off we go.  In reality, a careful reading of 
commonly accepted thesauruses (and I used Roget and Merriam-Webster) and an 
etymological dictionary (I used Barnhart's), convince me that "strategi" when 
originally put in the word lists, originally meant strategem or trick - an 
entirely different word, with a 400 year  different history in English, 
different origin in English than strategy, and possibly not even a completely 
shared derivation in Greek.  I am happy with "strategi" as "strategy" because 
it meets my needs, because strategy is a higher order concept than mere 
trickery, and because it is closer to what the concept of generalship (the 
Greek root) has evolved to become (but was not necessarily in Greek times).  
But it was that simple to change our language, and that is a little scary.

I admit freely that I am a novice to the language and that the list users 
have a significantly better understanding of Glosa than I do, and I hope you 
will take my comments with that caveat.  But, if anyone starts arguing in 
support of my idea about verb first ....

Walter

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] Suffixes As An Issue
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Mon, 08 Jul 2002 07:59:31 -0700

> vital issue - who has the authority to change the language?

Apparently just Wendy now. There is no official group.
I've suggested there should be one to carry it forward.

> (1) remain stable enough so that new users can learn it,

There have been no changes since approx 1980, AFAIK.
I think changes would help, but won't happen until we ...

> (2) have some accepted way to develop and incorporate changes,

There is a concept of "Mega-Glosa" whereby vocabulary is
taken from the common "international words". That plus a few
very basic rules of grammar should be sufficient; all the
other frills are detrimental and dispensable, IMO.

> If what I write today [...] is to be understandable to
> a Glosa reader in 20 years, stability is not a bad thing.

Glosa is a bridge language, an artificial auxiliary based
on existing national/natural languages, mainly consisting
of the scientific Greco-Latin "combining forms" and the
"international words" common to English/French/Spanish.
Its syntax is analytical, subject-verb-object, head-last.
Its morphology is minimal, 99% compounding, no inflections.
That's enough to work with, and set in stone.

> everyone agreed that "strategi" really means strategy,

All word meanings are negotiable and mutable, but Glosa is
not autonomic like Esperanto; even there, the vocab changed
drastically within a few years of its creator's death, in
the direction of "international" (western European) roots.
Lacking a Glosa dictionary, one could still guess most of
the words, though not their exact forms. (But no dictionary
can list literally all of the words of a living language.)

> originally meant strategem or trick - an entirely different word,

A word's meaning should not be overly-specific. Better to
use the broad meaning, and add more words for more precision.
It's easier to learn and use, and more stable in the long run.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] Suffixes As An Issue
From: Kevin Smith <kevins{at}qualitycode{dot}com>
Date: Mon, 08 Jul 2002 10:40:02 -0600

--- N0PSB{at}aol{dot}com wrote:
> But much of the conversation raises a vital issue - who has 
> the authority to change the language?

Wendy is the only person allowed to approve changes to the official language. I 
believe that technically makes the GID slightly unofficial, since I believe it 
contains a couple words that Wendy does not approve of (such as KE).

> As long as Glosa is a hobby activity for a few people, it is 
> reasonable for a half dozen people on a listserv to continually 
> modify it - to decide they like or don't like suffixes, for 
> example.  In the month or less I have been watching the mail, I 
> would say there have been at least a dozen modifications 
> suggested, some single words, some grammar rules, some 
> definitions, and at least one derivative language.

I agree with your concern that a language must be stable to become widespread 
and usable. Actually, the reason I started work on a derivative language was 
precisely because Glosa was _too_ stable. That is, I felt there were some 
glaring problems with it, and there was no structure within the Glosa community 
to get those problems fixed.

It's a typical IAL problem, of course. Most languages remain in flux for decades 
after their creation, and eventually people get tired of the churn. A few 
languages, like Esperanto and perhaps Glosa, have become stable but perhaps "too 
early" while the language was still immature. These langauges are certainly 
usable, and have many fine qualities. But in my opinion each has a few major 
problems that could be fixed in ways that would not render all existing text 
obsolete.

> If Glosa is to be more than a hobby, I would suggest the language 
> must do two things:
> 
> (1) remain stable enough so that new users can learn it, and

It has done this, in my opinion. 

> (2) have some accepted way to develop and incorporate changes, so 
> that those changes can be disseminated to the users.

It would be helpful to have a way to change the language other than convincing 
Wendy that the change is useful. Of course, any such process would run the risk 
of allowing the language to change too much. 

> If what I write today (and I just finished using the term mini-ra and 
> grafo-pe in a paper) is to be understandable to a Glosa reader in 20 
> years, stability is not a bad thing. 

We recently had some Glosa text posted to the list that everyone agreed was fine 
and readable. Later, we found out that it had been written something like ten 
years ago.

> I asked a question about "strategy" 
(snip)
> But it was that simple to change our language, 
> and that is a little scary.

Many Glosa words currently lack precise English definitions. That was my 
original Glosa project--creating a core list of about 1500 Glosa words that were 
clearly defined. I didn't want to change the language--just clarify it. The 
results are on my qualitycode.com web site, under Glosa (not Glo).

I tried to stick as close to Glosa as I could, but in some cases the definitions 
just didn't make sense. In some cases the meanings were vague, while in other 
cases there were multiple unrelated meanings tied to the same word.

So most of my effort was just clarifying, but along the way, I did end up 
changing the language in a few small places. But my changes were unofficial, and 
most seem unlikely to be accepted into the official language any time soon. 
Thus, my conclusion that Glosa is really quite static.

Which is why I launched Glo as my own sandbox to play in without offending 
anyone or having to try to convince someone of my proposals. Over time, Glo will 
diverge further from Glosa, and at some point will probably be renamed to 
reflect that.

Kevin

--- Robin Gaskell <rgaskell{at}zeta{dot}org{dot}au> wrote:
>    If we rigidify Glosa's structure (or try to), thus making it 'inhuman',
> we might get something equvalent to,
>   EG  He ran quickly, while still eating breakfast and heavily overloaded,
> to work.

I agree that this seems like an unpleasant sentence. But remember that with 
English the word itself usually provides a clue that it is an adverb. Glosa 
doesn't have that (thankfully).

The question goes back to whether Glosa should make life easy for the 
writer/speaker and hard for the reader/listener, or the other way around. And 
this may be driven by whether you see Glosa's future as being written or 
spoken.

A written language should clearly favor the reader, because any given work is 
likely to be read many times by many people, but only written once. The readers 
may be in a hurry, and the writer is more likely to have more time to think 
through the structure issues.

A spoken language should be more balanced, because there are likely to be fewer 
listeners (although still more listeners than speakers), and because speakers 
need to be able to throw sentences together in "real time". 

I dislike complex structures like Lojban because I think they would be too 
difficult to speak AND to understand when spoken. I could be wrong.

I believe that Glosa's number one priority should be to be really, really easy 
to read. Next, I would want it to be easy to speak and listen. Finally, it 
should be reasonable to write.

Given those priorities, rules that limit the structure pretty severely make a 
lot of sense. It helps readers and listeners a great deal. It also helps 
speakers, because simple rules can be applied quickly. Speakers also have the 
advantages of non-verbal communication to help them get their message across. 

>   In Glosa, modifiers precede the word they modify ('adjectives' before
> 'nouns'; and 'adverbs' before 'verbs'): note, there being no Part-of-Speech
> markers in Glosa, ~celero~ is used to translate both "fast" and "quickly." 
> 
>   IE  An pa kurso celero, tem du fago an prima vora, e fero excesi masi, ad
> an ergo-lo.   [Adverb content AFTER the verb as in English]

Shouldn't this be: "An pa celero kurso, tem..."?

>   But it might be kinder to the listener to break up the Adverbial element
> to give him, or her, psychological time to absorb the various modifications
> to the action.

I agree with this. I haven't figured out rules for it yet, but it seems like a 
good idea that works in practice.

>    I would hate to say that the BNF model, being only artificially
> intelligent, could possibly suffer from an excessive need for
> standardisation.  And it might be Politically Incorrect to suggest that
> good Glosa, being planned to make sense, ultimately, to human beings,
> possibly will not fit a rigidified structure.  However, I do venture such
> thoughts.

Glosa has to make sense to non-English speakers.

>   I would rearrange the sentence - according to my preferred emphasis - 
thus:-
> 
>  ~ 5)  Pro praxi, mi pa mite u bibli a tu.

I also find myself drawn to this structure, but find the comma to be inadequate. 
I'm still working on coming up with something better.

Kevin

Subject: Re: [glosalist] adverbs
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com

>>   In Glosa, modifiers precede the word they modify ('adjectives' before
>> 'nouns'; and 'adverbs' before 'verbs')

>> An pa kurso celero,

>> [Adverb content AFTER the verb as in English]

> Shouldn't this be: "An pa celero kurso, tem..."?

Using outmoded terms like "adverb" causes this confusion.
There are several very different things called adverbs.
This one seems to be an "adverb of manner". Whatever ...

Making the verb phrase too long looks unnatural.
Maybe "in a fast manner" or "with speed" would best
translate it, because the bare word doesn't really fit
anywhere or modify anything directly.

In both English and Vulgar Latin, they simply compounded
an adjective with "-lich" (body) or "-mente" (mind) and
let its position float. So then it'd be "kurso celero-menta"
or such, but then how to know where the direct object begins?

Glosa lacks a clear marker for transitivity, as does English.
Tok Pisin (Pidgin) has Glosa-like syntax, and uses "em" to
introduce a direct object. They also mark the start of the
verb phrase with "i", so syntax is greatly felicitated:

1. Famina kavalo i kurso kon celero. (Hungry horse runs fast.)
2. Celero kavalo i manduka em celeri. (Fast horse eats celery.)
3. Famina i kavalo a gastro. (Hunger gallops into the stomach.)

From: Kevin Smith <kevins{at}qualitycode{dot}com>

--- Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com wrote:
> Making the verb phrase too long looks unnatural.
> Maybe "in a fast manner" or "with speed" would best
> translate it, because the bare word doesn't really fit
> anywhere or modify anything directly.

Interesting post. I take it as a suggestion that perhaps, possibly, Glosa (or 
Glo, anyway) could abandon direct verb modifiers altogether. That is, you 
could/would not put any modifiers immediately before the verb--all verb 
modifiers would be connected with a preposition.

Moving to the other topic, I don't think Glosa really needs 'em' to indicate 
direct objects, as long as nouns are marked with u/plu or some other unambiguous 
flag. A noun phrase that comes after a verb without being introduced by a 
preposition _is_ the direct object. I'll think more about it though--perhaps 
using 'em' would help clarity or improve overall consistency.

Kevin

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] adverbs
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Sat, 13 Jul 2002 11:51:03 -0700

> I take it as a suggestion that perhaps, possibly, Glosa (or
> Glo, anyway) could abandon direct verb modifiers altogether. That is, you
> could/would not put any modifiers immediately before the verb--all verb
> modifiers would be connected with a preposition.

Not exactly -- all direct verb modifiers (usually called "auxiliaries")
fit nicely before the verb, but the more indirect ones (which in English
commonly take the -LY suffix) should be rendered with a preposition.

> Moving to the other topic, I don't think Glosa really needs 'em' to indicate
> direct objects, as long as nouns are marked with u/plu or some other unambiguous
> flag. A noun phrase that comes after a verb without being introduced by a
> preposition _is_ the direct object.

That's quite possible, as long as those pesky "indirect adverbs" (-LY words)
are always prepositioned -- otherwise they float around until they usurp
the D.O.'s position. As in the original CELERI example, where the preceding
direct-adverb seems stylistically too long for my taste, though not incorrect.

The general pattern in Glosa is for short modifiers to directly precede,
and long modifiers to follow the modifyee indirectly (i.e. after a
preposition), as in simple English syntax: "big cat" vs. "cat of huge size",
"he soon finished eating" vs. "he finished eating in a short time".
Thinking in this general pattern, we can avoid getting entangled by
odious and confusing grammatical terms like "adverb of manner", etc.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] More semi-Glosa experiments
From: Kevin Smith <kevins{at}qualitycode{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 21 Jul 2002 13:09:40 -0600

As most of you know, I have been designing a new language named Glo, which 
started as a 500 root subset of Glosa. The name of the language will be changing 
soon, to reflect the fact that it is no longer a pure subset of Glosa.

I offer my experiments here, in the hope that one or more might actually be 
useful in Glosa itself at some point. Of course, I don't expect (or want) Glosa 
to adopt any of them quickly (if at all). 

My language continues to be mostly compatible with Glosa. Out of the 455 roots, 
only 22 are not Glosa words, and most of those are Romance roots that would be 
recognizable by any Glosa-pe.

First, I have added CA as a verb phrase marker. VP must always start with CA, 
even if they are in the past or future. So you might say 'mi ca salta' or 'mi ca 
futuri salta'. At the moment, I have futuri/pasada instead of fu/pa, so 
non-Glosa-pe can recognize the intent. That may or may not change.

The subject always precedes the verb (precedes the CA), so it no longer needs to 
be marked as a noun. 'animali ca salta' is fine. You can omit the subject by 
starting the sentence with CA: 'ca nivi'.

I have introduced DA to mark a direct object. We already have prepositions to 
mark when an indirect object starts, so DA is kind of like a preposition just 
for direct objects. 'mi ca amo da animali'. 'mi ca pasada vendo da vegeta a tu' 
or, with the same meaning 'mi ca pasada vendo a tu da vegeta'.

Now, UNO is one/a/any, and U/UN is no longer needed as a noun phrase marker. PLU 
remains as plural/some, and also is no longer a noun phrase marker. While 
thinking about PLU, I realized that PLU TU would work fine for plural you, so I 
took VI out of the language.

Next, I expanded the role of CO. You can now say CO PERSONA to refer to the 
just-said-person, which would be "he/she/they/them". So I was able to remove MU 
from the language. CO KOSA is the just-said-thing, or "it", so ID could be 
removed from the language as well. 

Next, I got rid of U-CI/U-LA/PLU-CI/PLU-LA which I have always disliked. How? 
Well, I borrowed tricks from Tunu and Lingua Franca Nova, and probably others. 
First, I reversed the concept: instead of the-here for this, I have this-place 
for here.

So I need a word for "this", and I chose LE. LE actually means "the, this, 
that", depending on where you are pointing when you say it. Therefore, LE LOKA 
is here or there, depending on where you are pointing.

In writing, you more often really want to use a variant of CO, to refer to 
something you had referred to in the past. Or you want your writing to refer to 
itself, which can be handled like: 'se libra ca es boni'. (I haven't worked out 
the exact use of SE yet, but I think the general concept is solid).

All of this ended up removing several words, (including many of my least 
favorite Glosa words), while simplifying some rules and reducing the chance for 
ambiguity. I had to add only three words (CA, DA, LE). I think it is an 
improvement.

I have updated my website (including my BNF grammar rules) to reflect most of 
these changes: 
<http://www.qualitycode.com/html/glo-intro.eng.html>

Kevin

P.S. Here are my latest root changes to make Glo more Romance and less Greek:

bali -> lansa

> I offer my experiments here, in the hope that one or more might actually be
> useful in Glosa itself at some point.

Experimentation is good, especially since there is so little use of
Glosa-as-it-is-today. The basic concepts of Glosa, analytic syntax
and international vocabulary, are certainly a good foundation.
Clearly some further evolution is necessary. Many of the ideas
you suggest seem worth a trial ...

> Now, UNO is one/a/any, and U/UN is no longer needed as a noun phrase marker.

That seems especially good; the highest frequency words should
be mnemonic and euphonic, both.

> So I need a word for "this", and I chose LE. LE actually means "the, this,
> that", depending on where you are pointing when you say it. Therefore, LE LOKA
> is here or there, depending on where you are pointing.

I like the LE, but there's also LA for "that, there". All languages
make "deictic" distinctions like this/that, here/there, etc.
You could use both LE and LA in the same sentence as in the English
use of "the former" and "the latter", or what linguists call
the proximate/obviative. Very useful.

> In writing, you more often really want to use a variant of CO, to refer to
> something you had referred to in the past. Or you want your writing to refer to
> itself, which can be handled like: 'se libra ca es boni'. (I haven't worked out
> the exact use of SE yet, but I think the general concept is solid).

The more natural way is to use "this/that". I don't trust a-priori
inventions such as Glosa's -CO, they never work out in the real world.

> P.S. Here are my latest root changes to make Glo more Romance and less Greek:

Originally, Interglossa was largely Greek because it was thought the
international scientific vocabulary would rule the futuristic day.
But scientists now have abandoned Greek for coining new terms, and
the horrible medical/legal terminology seems to be going permanently
out of fashion. Glosa evolved toward Latin, with the remaining Greek
words so disfigured in orthography as to become unrecognizeable and,
worse, conflict with well-known latinate words. A pure-Greek or
Koine version of Glosa would be very interesting, but impractical.
So I vote to exile them all and retain only modern latinate words.
And then, reconsider the case of K vs. C, as the Roman Senate did.

That's exactly what Glosa desperately needs, more true Romance.
The auxlang that attracts the most teenyboppers will surely win.

afirma. si tu ca uti da mi sa lingua (no Glosa), tu ca sio dice "mi ca amo". si

mi ca zero pote puta de uno exempla. anti co, le idea ca es u proba. mi ca sio

Not that I can think of, but it is an experiment. I would be interested in

>> And then, reconsider the case of K vs. C, as the Roman Senate did.

> Reconsider? What do you mean? "c" instead of "k" as i suggested? What did
> the senate do anyway?

Glosa uses K in a pseudo-Greek attempt at pseudo-phoneticism.
This single step renders all the familiar words of civilization
that happen to include a C (approx 33%) unrecognizeable.
The great linguist (interlinguist) Otto Jesperson, who first
devised the IPA (international phonetic alphabet) tried this
approach in his auxlang Novial, circa 1927, but by 1930 he
saw the error of his ways and reformed it by un-K-ing it.
I feel that Glosa should do likewise rather than cleaving
to false grecianity. In the old days, as today, governments
high-handedly tampered with technological standards such as
orthography and terminology (gobbledegook). Latin was never
as stable as we might think, having diverse dialects (like
British vs. American vs. Texan today) and constantly mutating
its alphabet (C G K Q V J ...) I tried to find a nice summary
URL but couldn't (using google.com) but you can well imagine.

Subject: Re: [glosalist] More semi-Glosa experiments
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Tue, 23 Jul 2002 12:55:53 -0700

>> Glosa uses K in a pseudo-Greek attempt at pseudo-phoneticism.
>> This single step renders all the familiar words of civilization
>> that happen to include a C (approx 33%) unrecognizeable.

> Unless you listen to what you're saying.

It's a popular fallacy to believe that pronunciation
(of soft C, for instance) is similar in most places.
Pronunciation varies more and faster than spelling:
"C" is /k/, /ts/, /S/, /tS/, /s/, /z/, /C/, or ...
and 99% of all auxlang usage is written, not spoken.
As it is, even English speakers who share a common
written language can barely follow movie dialog
from the far ends of the old British Empire.

>> approach in his auxlang Novial, circa 1927, but by 1930 he
>> saw the error of his ways and reformed it by un-K-ing it.

> Did he have "hard" always "c" (ie: c=k), which is teh Roman,
> and the logical way, or hard and soft?

If you allow either hard or soft, you can always use hard
if you like, as is often suggested in Latin courses. But,
if you use 2 different letters then you must dissimilate
the pronunciations, and then the same old problem recurs.
Logic must be deep, not superficial; etymology is an abyss.
Jesperson, champion phoneticist, eventually capitulated.

The solution is to spell C/K/Q with C, allow pronunciation
to float anywhere between hard and soft. In other words,
accept natural commonly observed variations as allophones
of the mighty C phoneme. It will happen anyway, nobody can
stop it; even in Esperanto people do it, violating their
own rules as usual. Read some Glosa aloud, as soon as
your guard falls, they're baaaack!

> Why did they have 3 [k] sounds in the Romabet?

Random historical accidents dented their logical jalopy.
It isn't known whether they stole it from local Greeks
or Etruscans, with different alefbethic "colors" already
(maybe because the Etruscans emigrated relatively early),
probably both. Romans adapted the Grecobet to their own
mongrel Italic, which lacked many of the Greccish sounds
and changed others (like Z to R -- was it their diet?).
Phonetic debris really accumulates across the millenia.

But we need to simplify if we want a nice easy bridge
language for adults to pick up in a week. Pronunciation
must be EXTREMELY EASY, and Glosa is DIFFICULT. So:

H ->     ...  already is silent for most people
J -> GI  ...  or maybe J -> I
K -> CU  ...  better than K -> C
Q -> C   ...  Spanish does this
W -> V   ...  better than W -> U
X -> S   ...  or maybe X -> C
Y -> I   ...  many langs do this
Z -> S   ...  a rose is a roze

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: Re: [glosalist] alphabet (Saluta plu ami!)
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Fri, 26 Jul 2002 11:46:35 -0700

> Look, if we're starting with an inventid language, atleat make it one
> letter per sound! "ku" would be "ku", "kv" would be "kv", that's that!
> People are capable of saying both - it's not one sound, but two!

Glosa is not a purely invented language. It takes vocabulary from
existing languages, and is intended to enable a billion people
from cultures speaking those languages to inter-communicate.
For an apriori language, better try Loglan or Klingon. Even there,
you never get uniform pronunciation from adults who learn it.
Only children can learn to pronounce a language perfectly, and
they always mutate (creolize) language in unpredictable ways.
The only safe option is a neutral fixated spelling with locally
varying pronunciation, as with Medieval Latin for 1000 years.

> English and French spelling is messed up, badly. Spanish is mostly highly
> logical, but there are still problems. These should simply be absent when
> creating a new orthography.

English spelling of its Greco-Latinate vocabulary is pretty good,
but pronunciation sucks in diverse splendor. French is similar
though with less diversity. Spanish is entirely illogical in
the way you complained of, since it uses many ways to spell and
pronounce the same root/stem in its derivative series. Add also
Italian and Portuguese to the mix; one well-known Interlingua
has managed to find the common central tendency and produced
a dictionary which is online. I've done that algorithmically
from public bilingual word-lists, and simplified the spelling
by eliminating redundant letters. That's all anybody can do.

>> hard enough even in writing, where you must look up
>> every word in a dictionary.

> Just like Glosa I'd say! In fact due to the increased length of words in
> Ido, i'd say that they're easier to remember.

You're right about that. Experiments seem to show that to retain
mnemonic value, root/stems need to be more like FELIN than FELE.
Still bisyllabic, as most Glosa words are, but with the extra
consonant as an etymological clue. Then we must either terminate
each word with a schwa sound (workable) or add a part-of-speech
or cosmetic vowel (probably unworkable).

>> Logically you could better use
>> numbers instead of words, with decimal points to mark off
>> the affixes.

> I was talking about spelling dude!

But numbers are indexes. Each language can be indexed and then
machine translation is easy as pi to whatever precision desired.
That's basically the UNL idea ...

>> Latin is not simple, and is dead.

> I meant a simpliFIED latin - and because it's dead, it's neutral.

No good, you must coin new words, BEISBOL LAZER KIMCHI ...
Revise the suffixes and words would become twice as long,
completely un-mnemonic, ridiculous-at-1st-sight. Esperanto
attempted to recode Latin (into Slavic) and doesn't work.

>> Whereas half the world today
>> speaks English/Spanish/French/Portuguese, and they all mix well.

> That's not Glosa though!

Find a root that is in Glosa but not in E/F/P/S. It's tough to do.
The semantics of the roots are also imported to G. The syntax is
essentially Romanic except adj-noun backward as in Germanic.
Glosa is essentially Ido minus affixes (an old joke).

> -o as noun, -a as adjective is very easy methinks.

Ah, the vowel game again. Originally there was light p-o-s marking
in Glosa, but it was dropped around 1970. Why not use Ido for that?
With a little cleansing of roots, and more naturalistic suffixes,
Ido might become very practical -- and then be renamed Occidental.
Glosa hates verbs, adjectives, and all other archaic grammatical
terminology (and doesn't offer anything to replace it).

Latino sine Flexione
/ Interlingua de Peano

Idea de literatura mundiale, que Herder et Goethe habe intellecto praecipue
ex puncto de visu de arte, habe hodie acquisito, ex puncto de visu de
scientia, sensu etiam majore. Nam, de commune possesiones de genere humano,
hihil es tam generale et internationale quam scientia. Sed omne
communicatione et propagatione de scientia ute auxilio de lingua, et ita
internationalitate de scientia postula in modo irresistibile
internationalitate de lingua. Si nos considera, que hodie plure opere
scientifico, in particulare tractatus, es translato in duodecim vel plus
lingua extero, tunc nos cognosce quale immane mole de labore pote es
praeservato, si libros, ubicumque in terra, pote es aequaliter intellecto in
generale, sicut per exemplo notas musicale aut tabulas de logarithmos.

Interlingua / IALA

Le idea de literatura mundial que Herder e Goethe concipeva essentialmente
ex li puncto de vista del arte, ha nunc ganate ancora multo plus grande
importantia ex li puncto de vista del scientia. Nam de omne commun
possessiones del humanitate necun es tam vermente general e international
quam le scientia. Sed omne communication e propagation del scientia usa le
medio del lingua. Tunc le internationalitate del scientia irresistibilemente
postula le internationalitate del lingua. Si nos considera, que hodie plure
obras scientific, specialmente libros de insenio, se trova traducite in
dece-duo o plus linguas estranietunc nos comprende qual immense quantitate
de labor on economisarea, si on poterea tanto generalmente comprender libros
ubicumque apud le globo como assi notas musical o tabulas de logarithmos.

Occidental / Interlingue

Li ide' pri mund-literature, quel Herder e Goethe hat conceptet essentialmen
ex li vidpunctu del arte, ha nu gan'at ancor mult plu grand importantie ex
li vidpunctu del scientie. Nam de omni comun possedages del homanite' niun
es tam vermen general e international, quam scientie. Ma omni comunication e
trnasmediation del scientie usa li medie del lingue. Do liinternationalita'
del scientie inresistibilmen postula li internationalita' del lingue. Si noi
considera, que hodie pluri sciential ovres, specialmen libres de aprension,
trova se traductet in decidu o plu foren lingues, tande noi comprende quel
immens quantita' de labor on vell economisar, si on vell posser comprender
libres partu' sur li glob sam generalmen quam por exemples notes o tabelles
de logaritmes.

Esperanto

La ideo pri mondliteraturo, kiun Herder kaj Goethe konceptis chefe el la
vidpunkto de la arto, akiris nun el la vidpunkto de la scienco multe pli
gravan signifon. Char el la komunaj posedajhoj de la homaro, neniu estas
tiel vere ghererala kaj internacia kiel la scienco. Sed chiu komunikado kaj
disvastigado de la scienco uzas la helpilon de la lingvo kaj tial la
internacieco de la scienco nerezisteble postulas la internaciecon de la
lingvo. Se ni konsideras, ke nuntempe kelkaj sciencaj verkoj, precipe
lernolibroj, estas tradukitaj en dek du au pli da fremdaj lingvoj, tiam ni
komprenas, kiom granda kvanto da laboro povus esti shparata, se libroj chie
en la mondo povus esti tiel ghenerale komprenataj kiel ekzemple la
muziknotoj au logaritmaj tabeloj.

Ido

La ideo pri mondo-litaraturo, quan Herder e Goethe konceptabis esence del
vidpunto dil arto, ganis nun del vidpunto dil cienco mem plu granda importo.
Nam del kozi, quin la homaro posedas komune, nula es tam vere universala ed
internaciona kam la cienco. Or, omna komunikado e propagado dil cienco uzas
la moyeno dil linguo, do la interacioneso dil cienco postulas nerezisteble
la internacioneso dil linguo. Se ni konsideras, ke cadie sat multa ciencala
verki, specale lernolibri, tradukesas aden dekedu o plu multa stranjera
lingui, ni komprenas, qua enorma quanto de laboro povus sparesar, se libri
omnaloke sur la terglobo povus komprenesar tam generale, kam exemple muzikal
noti o logaritmala tabeli.

Novial

Li idee pri mondo-literature, kel Herder e Goethe koncepted esentialim fro
li vidpunctu del arte, ha nun ganat mem multim plu grand importanteso fro li
vidpunctu del scientie. Den ek li coses kel li homaro posese comunim, nuli
is tam verim general e international kam li scientie. Or omni comunico e
meditatione del scientie usa li moyene del lingue, dunke li internationaleso
del scientie demanda nonresistablim li internationaleso del lingue. Si nus
considera ke disdi pluri sciential verkes, particularim lernolibres, es
traductet en dekdu e plu multi lingues, tand nus comprenda qui imensi
quanteso de laboro povud bli sparat, si libres povud omnilok sur li globe
bli comprendat tam generalim kam exemplim musical notes o tabeles de
logaritmes.

*   Although I have not seen it, this EuroWordNet sounds very promising as a vocabulary standard.  Is it available on the Net?


    What is the next step for the Glosalist group were we to move to standardise the lexicon, and derive functional wordlists at these various levels?  I would put in a plea, here, for adding a few of the Glosa synonyms for the very common concepts, such as "water" - if not at the Mid Learner Level (2441), then at the Glosa Standard Level (5437).


    For me, when I tried my hand at creative writing in Glosa, the avoidance of unnecessary repetition was stylistically essential.  So, if we want people to actually write small booklets in Glosa, then we do not want to put off such creative people by what they could perceive to be the ^straight jacket^ of a rigidly enforced one_concept/one_word rule. 


Saluta,

At 21:51 04/12/2001 -0800, Kevin Smith grafo:
>--- Sydpidd{at}aol{dot}com wrote:
>> id feno a mi ke in glosa, u verba "ge" du habe bi
>> funktio.
>
>Tu nota pa solo monstra mo funktio, mi du kredi: Vice u SVO
>a OVS.
>
>> "ge u frasi du grafo per mi". 
>> "u frasi du grafo per mi, ge"   
>
>Plu-ci du feno xeno, a mi. Posi solo kausa mi maxi-ski
>Engla-lingua. Anti-co, mi pa pote logi plu bi.
>
*   Mi habe plu problema ko bi de plu-ci frasa.

    Sid, si tu loka uno England-lingua "gloss" infra singo Glosa frasa, na
pote habe asura de tu tende.  Mi ne cogita uti ~ge~ iso tu pa akti, intra
alo de tu frasa.

Posi:- 
       "ge u frasi du grafo per mi". 
      [get a sentence writing by me]
       get a sentence written by me

  Re-grafo,
       ~Gene u frasa ge-grafo ex mi.~
     [get a sentence got-write from me]
       Get a sentence written by me.

Pluso:
       "u frasi du grafo per mi, ge"   
      [a sentence writing by me, get]*

   Nuli tem, intra plu pagina de Plu Glosa Nota, mi pa vide u verbi, ~ge~
to u fini de u frasa.  U tali uti sembla kontra plu regula de u sintaxi de
Glosa.  Simi, un uti de ~ge~, no-jugo ad ali hetero verbi, to u komence de
u frasa ne sembla eqa Glosa sintaxi.

   Mi memo de u krea de ~ge~, alo ~ge-~, es iso u brevi forma de ~gene~.

   Kron plu Glosa-pe pa prima petitio Ron Clark de un 'no-akti voka', Ron
ne vo habe ali hetero situa de un 'akti voka'.  Anti-co, plu Glosa-pe pa
kontinu mu petitio, e Ron pa vide u kaso de Deutsch-lingua, in qi mu habe u
`ge-X` forma pro u deskribe-verbi ex un akti-verbi [participle].  So, an
krea, ex ~gene~ e u Deusch-lingua `ge-` u Glosa ~ge-~.

   An a-nu pa lose un akti-verbi:-

      ~U ju-an dice id.~          ~U ju-an ge-dice id.~
     [the boy says it]           [the boy got-speak it]
      The boy says it.             The boy spoken it.*
                               *Il es nuli kompleti akti-verbi.

   So, Ron pa decide de uti u neutrali akti-verbi, e pa selekti ~gene~.

      ~U ju-an gene dice id.~*    ~U ju-an gene ge-dice id.~++
     [the boy gets speak it]      [the boy gets spoken it]      
    *U frasa habe bi akti-verbi.  ++~id~ nece es u no-direkti objekti.

Posi:
      ~U ju-an gene ge-dice ex id.~+++      
      [the boy gets spoken by it]
    +++No-korekti semani.

Korekti 'no-akti voka':
      ~Id gene ge-dice ex u ju-an.~   
     [it gets spoken by the boy]
       It is said by the boy.

Tu praxi:
       Muta ~U ju-an dice de id.~ in no-akti voka.

  (Posi tu logi Ron basi pro evita no-akti voka intra Glosa.)

Saluta, 

Robin Gaskell

Plu pre-parenta de plu kani es plu lupus; qi eko in
plu mega asocia grega e habe plu mega neokortika; u
logika area de enkefa. So mu matematika tekno pa sio
pote uti te puta u numera de mu plu pro- e anti-pe in
mu grega Â u auxi tem evolve.

Plu zoa, exempla plu avi e rode-zoa, pote detekti u ma
mega ex bi kumu. Sed te numera, u zoa nece logi; singu
ra in grega gene dona u numera e un ultima numera in
seri eqa un numera de panto ra in grega.

Poli primata habe u-ci basi matematika tekno. Sed
Robert Young; u zoa-akti tekno-pe de Pontifika
Katolika Universita de Minas Gerais in Belo Horizonte,
Brazil; pa kredi; plu kani habe id plus.

Te examina u idea, Young e an asocia; Rebecca West de
De Montfort Universita in Lincoln, UK; uti u mode; qi
pa gene uti te demonstra; plu babi; qi habe pen meno;
pote numera.

Plura ludi pupa gene loka ante babi, e po-co u skuta
gene leva te kripti mu. Po-co un infanti skope, tem
plu pupa gene pluso alo apo; pre u skuta gene kata te
monstra u fini vista.

Si un experimenta-pe pa pluso alo apo u pupa tem babi
ne skope, u babi skope plu pupa, tem ma mega tem; ka,
akorda pe doxo, u numera de plu pupa ne eqa u numera
ge-puta ex babi.

Young e West pa itera u experimenta per mo-mo
ge-mixa-kulti kani e plu kani gluko-sito-mero. Iso plu
babi, plu kani pa skope plu kratera, tem ma mega tem;
kron plu suma ne es veri. Plu kani skope minus mega
interese; kron mo plus mo mero eqa bi mero; sed mu
gene pusi turba; kron, exempla, mo plus mo mero feno
eqa tri mero, ka akti ex plu experimenta-pe. 

Plu detekti de plu recerka-pe fu gene reporta in mo ex
plu fu publika-ra de ÂAnimal CognitionÂ.




Dogs can count. Dogs are descended from wolves, which
not only have a large neocortex - the brain's centre
of reasoning - but live in large social groups. So
their mathematical ability could, in evolutionary
terms, have been useful for working out how many
allies and enemies they had in a pack, the researchers
think.

Animals such as birds and rodents can tell when one
pile of objects is bigger than another. But to count,
an animal has to recognise that each object in a set
corresponds to a single number and that the last
number in a sequence represents the total number of
objects.

Many primates have this basic mathematical ability.
But Robert Young, an animal behaviour expert at the
Pontifical Catholic University of Minas Gerais in Belo
Horizonte, Brazil, suspected that dogs do too.

To test the idea, Young and his colleague Rebecca West
of De Montfort University in Lincoln, UK, borrowed a
technique that has been used to show that
five-month-old babies can count. 

A number of toy dolls are placed in front of a baby
and then a screen is raised to hide them. The infant
then watches as some dolls are added or taken away
before the screen is lowered to reveal the final
result. 

If the experimenter has played a trick and
surreptitiously added or taken away a doll, the baby
looks at the dolls for much longer, presumably because
he or she had done the calculation and the number of
dolls contradicts the baby's expectations.

Young and West repeated the experiment on 11 mongrels
using doggie treats. Sure enough, the dogs stared at
the bowls for much longer when the sums did not add
up. 

Dogs paid little attention when one plus one treat
resulted in two treats, the researchers will report in
an upcoming issue of Animal Cognition. But they were
confused when the experiment was manipulated to show
that one plus one treat appeared to equal three
treats, for example.

> Plu pre-parenta de plu kani es plu lupus

> Dogs are descended from wolves

A good demonstration of PLU not working well as a pluralizer
or as a noun-phrase tag. Stripping it down to pidgin level:
"Arkeo parenta de kani es lupus". Yummy! IMO. (Except that
"wolf" should be "lobo" to fit the predominant phonology.)

> Plu zoa [...] Animals [... ] u zoa [...] an animal

> Poli primata [...] Many primates

POLY and MONO both strike me as being apt and beautiful,
but PLU and U/UN are what a Texan might call plug-ugly.
Compare with Ido's nice -O singular and -I plural suffixes.
Italian has "I" for a plural article, maybe Glosa should
borrow it to replace PLU: "u zoa pa vora i zoa". And then
PLU could return to its normal duty, meaning "more".

There have now been some notes to Glosalist, in Glosa and English.  One 
member commented (in Eng) on the one thing that always leaps out at me in 
Glosa texts: the use, or overuse of the pluralizer/article 'plu'.  For 
instance, in one text, 'plu' is used three times in the equivalent of the 
Eng sentence:

The wolf is the ancestor of the dog.

Now, national languages handle such sentences in different ways, but in 
creoles they are always handled in the same way: by zero marking of the 
plural, because in:

Wolves are ancestors of dogs.

_all_ the plurals are nonspecific.  You are not refering to particular or 
presupposed wolves, ancestors or dogs, but those things in general.  For 
Novial J proposed an unmarked number-indeterminate form in -e, which is 
similar in fact to the creole situation.  The marking of nonspecific plurals 
in Glosa does seem to be excessive - if a nonspecific plural needs to be 
marked once in a sentence, does it really need to be marked three times?

There was also a question about the form of 'plu'.  I agree with the member 
who said that 'plu' is best reserved for the positive comparative.  I 
started looking at creole pluralizers: how about 'nan' from Pu, or 'ban' 
from Fr-based creoles (< Fr 'bande de')?

Kordiale, James Chandler

Yet another (pseudo-)parser for Glosa ... 

Like Charles ( http://catty.com/~catty/lang/dict.cgi ), Alexander and 
Syd before, I tried to write a little program, that helps to translate
from and into Glosa by looking up the words of a text in a dictionary.

You can read more about it and get it from my website, 
http://www.glosa.org/en/glosatra.htm .  Mi spe; tu fu habe hedo ko id.
Saluta - Marcel.




Properties 

* Glosatra is a primitive command line program for the console.  It
  has no menus, mouse support, graphics and things like that.
* It can "translate" Glosa-English and English-Glosa.
* The program finds words, word groups and compounds with and
  without hyphem in the dictionary.
* It tries to give a suggestion even if the final vowel of the
  Glosa word in the text is wrong.
* It tries to recognize English words, even if they are not in the
  basic form.
* No case sensitivity: capitalization or not does not matter.
* It can use always the latest version of the GID.  Please download
  the new version.
* Load and run, - no complicated installation because of its
  simplicity.
* Runs on MS-DOS/Windows and Linux.  It could certainly run on
  other platforms, too.  The source code is offered on the web.
* It can use standard-I/O-streams.  So it could be easily started and
  used by other programs, even within a text editor.
* It does in no way claim to be errorfree, professional or
  comfortable.

What is 'du', a progressive/nonpunctual aspect marker?  Then why is it being 
used with a stative verb (be)?  It is like saying in Eng:

The dog is being a loyal pet.

My main point is: I dont see why any articles are needed at all.  Lets look 
at the 1928 Novial equivalent:

Hunde es fidindi haus-animale.

In creoles, such nonspecific plural NPs would be zero-marked (no articles, 
no pluralizers).  I dont see why in Glosa you cant just say:

Kani es/eqa fide domi-zoa.

There is nothing that needs to be added to this sentence to express the 
desired meaning.

> What is 'du', a progressive/nonpunctual aspect marker?

The authors of Glosa were/are blissfully unaware of such things.
I regard DU XXX as English XXX-ING, and GE XXX as English XXX-ED.
So a more direct answer would be "Yes, more or less, in effect,
but not rigorously enough for Bickerton or creole enthusiasts".
Glosa is essentially a relexed Basic English ...

> My main point is: I dont see why any articles are needed at all.

Because we must express definiteness and number somehow, but
Glosa does not provide gracefully appropriate particles; it
turns English "A/AN" into "U/UN" but then decrees it to both
a definite and indefinite singular article ... thus confusion.

I know that Bickerton grandly claims to have discovered the
universal creole grammar, but I tossed his nonsense out with
that of Chomsky; creoles can damned-well have articles, and
I believe that Glosa does need one more (the definite "LA").
With the 3 of them (U singular, and some better plural than
PLU) we could all be happy and frustrate some linguists too.

I only meant 'I dont see why articles are needed at all in this sentence', 
not in Glosa as a whole.  Creoles have articles but only uses them with 
specific NPs (either presupposed-specific (definite) or asserted-specific 
(indefinite)).  They usually have a plural def art or pluralizer, but this 
would not be used in sentences like Nick's.  I dont see why the same system 
could not be used in Glosa.

>I know that Bickerton grandly claims to have discovered the
>universal creole grammar, but I tossed his nonsense out with
>that of Chomsky; creoles can damned-well have articles, and
>I believe that Glosa does need one more (the definite "LA").
>With the 3 of them (U singular, and some better plural than
>PLU) we could all be happy and frustrate some linguists too.

I am not here to defend Bickertons ideas, much less Chomskys, but I do think 
that those designing IALs with isolating grammar would do well to look at a 
variety of creoles to see what can be learnt from them.

James Chandler wrote:
> >Kevin's - Uno kani du es u fide socia-zoa.
 
> What is 'du', a progressive/nonpunctual aspect
> marker?  Then why is it being 
> used with a stative verb (be)?  

Yes. In normal Glosa, ~du~ is progressive/nonpunctual
aspect marker. Kevin is just using it to mark the
start of the verb phrase. We had a lot of discussion a
while ago on how to identify which word in a Glosa
sentence is the verb. This was one proposed solution.
Many people feel there is a similar problem with
sentence adverbs, when they are not placed before the
verb.

~Fe pa face plu vasa tekno.~ 
  [She made the vases skilfully.] 

Where at first glance ~tekno~ looks to be the object
of the sentence. You can, of course, rearrange the
sentence.

~Fe pa face plu vasa ko tekno.~
~Fe pa tekno face plu vasa.~

I don't have a problem with the original sentence,
which could be said to be "syntactically ambiguous",
but is not "semantically ambiguous".

 
> My main point is: I dont see why any articles are
> needed at all.  Lets look 
> at the 1928 Novial equivalent:
> 
> Hunde es fidindi haus-animale.

I note that in O.J.'s book on your site it says

"Indefinite number. ..... a form which was neither
singular nor plural .... Now it is easy in N to make
such forms by simply leaving out the final vowel, thus
'hom' would mean "man or woman or men or women"; this
would be particularly useful in the generic sense
(i.e. when speaking of the whole species), e.g. leon
es kruel, where we say indifferently `the lion is
cruel' (or `a lion is cruel') or `lions are cruel.' "
 
> In creoles, such nonspecific plural NPs would be
> zero-marked (no articles, 
> no pluralizers).  I dont see why in Glosa you cant
> just say:
> 
> Kani es/eqa fide domi-zoa.

I think it's fine to say it that way, but I wonder if
you think it is the only way to say it?

Another quote from O.J.'s book -
"nationali lingues non es apti por es mondelingues"

~plu natio lingua ne es gru de es plu munda lingua~ !

Plu ami saluta ex
Nick

--- Nicholas Hempshall <nick_hempshall{at}yahoo{dot}co{dot}uk> wrote:
> Or literally -
> 
> youth man pleasure guidance intensity speed vehicle
> 
> I'll open it to the list to suggest any other
> interpretations, else it must be unambiguous.

Well, some phrases are unambigous upon first glance, and others are unambigous 
upon lengthy study. I'm not certain, but I suspect this falls into the second 
category.

As I have said before, when I read something like this I assume everything is 
part of the noun phrase (mostly adjectives) until I find a verb flag. So I would 
start out as:

Youthful masculine pleasure-oriented guide-related strong fast vehicle.

No verb. Well, everything seemed fine before guide, so in this case I would 
guess that guide is the verb:

Young masculine pleasure guides/drives strong fast vehicles. Nope.

Youth(ness) masculinely drives strong fast cars. Well, perhaps in poetry one 
might say something like this, but it would be unusual.

I would also wonder if the writer had left out some prepositions, or perhaps had 
 misspelled a word. Or, perhaps you were using some regional idiom without even 
realizing it. After several minutes of consideration, I would probably reach the 
same conclusion that you did about the intended meaning.

Is that they process an IAL should rely on for communication? It would be so 
much easier with VP and NP markers (nu/du/ca, u/plu/da)

juve andro VP hedo duce NP forti tako vagona.

Simple. Unambiguous.

Kevin

>> youth man pleasure guidance intensity speed vehicle

Chinese uses compounds a lot. Add hyphens and it's clearer.
Chinese also has a tradition of poetic 4-morpheme adages.
But in real life they use unambiguous verbs and markers.

> It would be so much easier with VP and NP markers

One could mark default part-of-speech, at least noun vs. verb,
in the lexicon, and then to change one to the other would require
an inflectional suffix or preposition. Or one could say that
any open-class word can function as noun or verb. The authors
have chosen the latter approach, though somewhat inconsistently.
To those who enjoy puzzles and ciphers, the former is preferable.
It is tempting to use the terminal vowel on each word to indicate
the part-of-speech, like some other IALs and Interglossa did.

Qo-mode pe debi akti de lakrima infanti?

1. Fikti; id ne acide. Taci es no-facili. Plu proxi-pe
du xeno skope pe. Pe nece feno; pe senti zero etio.  

2. Trakto id konski a uno-ra hetero. U-ci funktio pusi
tem. U infanti gene ski u mode de gene reakti ex pe.
Pe fu nece ergo ma forti fu-kron.

3. Simpati. Un infanti ne volu pe simpati. Id volu; pe
reakti. Id gene ski; pe es debili.

4. Voci. Plu proxi-pe du ma xeno skope pe. Un infanti
du lakrima ko klu ma forti fono. Pe ne pote kripto; pe
senti etio.

5. Cede. Un infanti fu panto-tem gene qod id volu. Pe
fu habe zero paci.

6. Ridi anti id. Pe gene ma forti fono e ma frustra.

7. Puni. Pe gene klu ma forti fono de pe doxo es posi
ex mikro homi. Un infanti habe koleri anti pe. Id fu
atende id okasio. Kura!

8. Lauda panto boni-akti. U-ci es fo-forti ergo. Posi,
ka id es kontra-logika alo ka pe plu parenta ne akti
so. Sed un infanti gene ski hedo akti boni. E panto-pe
habe hedo.


Poli ami saluta ex
Nick



How ought one deal with a crying child?

1 Pretend that is not happening. Being silent is hard.
The people around you, are looking at you strangely.
You have to seem as though you feel no blame.

2. Draw its attention to something else. This works
for short time. The child learns the way to get your
attention. You will need to work harder next time.

3. Sympathy. The child does want your pity. It wants
you to react. It learns that you are week.

4. Shout. The people around you are looking at you
more strangely. The chid is crying even louder. You
cannot hide your shame.

5. Give in. The child will always get what it wants.
You will have no peace.

6. Make fun of it. You get more noise and more
frustration.

7. Punishment. You get even more noise than you think
is possible from a small person. The child resents
you. It will await its opportunity. Look out!

8. Praise all good behaviour. This is very hard work.
Perhaps, because it is counter-intuitive or because
you parents didnÂt behave in this way with you. But
the child learns to enjoy behaving well. And everyone
is happy.

> Although I have not seen it, this EuroWordNet sounds very promising
> as a vocabulary standard.  Is it available on the Net?

Yes and yes. They tried to identify word-concepts common to
3 or more European languages, and not just the usual 3 ...
Try searching google.com for the latest URLs. Also, the
original English WordNet has now advanced to a newer revision,
and I'm trying to find enthusism enough to download it;
it can be tested on-line, i.e. through a web-page form.

> What is the next step for the Glosalist group were we to
> move to standardise the lexicon, and derive functional
> wordlists at these various levels?

Long ago we collected and combined some English word lists,
and I recently upgraded it. It's sorted into frequency levels
like the old Thorndike/Eaton list (which served as the basis
for IALA's interlingua dictionary). I think you want something
similar for Glosa, and the easiest way I can think of is to
collect "votes" from several people as to relative importance
of each Glosa word, then combine the scores to obtain a list
from which you can take the top 1000 or howevermany you like.

> we do not want to put off such creative people by what they
> could perceive to be the ^straight jacket^ of a rigidly
> enforced one_concept/one_word rule.

There is not and can never be such a rule in the real world.
Actually, I find the Glosa 6000+1800 (full set) inadequate.
According to the rules of Mega-Glosa, all the international
words are included, not just the ones listed; I'd rather
throw out the listed lexicon than exclude them. (A good
source might be the on-line IALA dictionary -- why not?)

To: auxlang{at}listserv{dot}brown{dot}edu
Subject: [glosalist] Isolating grammar
From: "James Chandler" <idojc{at}hotmail{dot}com>
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 2002 19:59:26 +0000
Cc: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au

Judging from some of the recent discussions on the Glosa list, although 
isolating grammar is definitely the way forward for any new IAL, I wonder 
whether interlinguists are yet in a position to really develop a suitable 
isolating grammar for an IAL.  There seems to be a real lack of 
understanding, or what I would call _technique_, when it comes to utilizing 
the possibilities of isolating structure in IAL grammar.  For example, I 
cannot bring myself to accept that there is no altenative to using a 
distinctive ending for each part of speech in order to clarify which is the 
noun, which is the verb etc. in a Glosa sentence.  The fact that people are 
having recourse to such devices really demonstrates the lack of any kind of 
technological advancement in this area.

What I think we could do with as a preliminary to any such discussions, is 
some kind of complete (or at least rich) theory of the possibilities of 
isolating structure.  What I am suggesting is that, prior to trying to 
develop an IAL based in isolating grammar, we equip ourselves with a Theory 
of Isolating Grammar.  So that when we want to know how we can distinguish 
noun from verb, we can refer to an established theory which will tell us a) 
what the possibilities are, and b) what implications each one has for the 
rest of the grammar.

In IAL discussions, the kind of answers to questions we commonly ask tend to 
be completely different when one leaves behind morphology and considers only 
isolating solutions.  For example:

Plurals.  Traditionally we ask: should we form plurals in -s, -i or -j?  In 
an isolating grammar this becomes: should we use a plural article or a 
pluralizer?  Should a pluralizer be obligatory when plurality is otherwise 
indicated?  Should a pluralizer be used with nonspecifics?  and so on.

In this and other instances, the whole debate seems to expand beyond 
recognition once morphology is renounced, almost like going from Euclidean 
to non-Euclidean geometry, or from Newtons laws to Einsteins.  The 
possibilities suddenly multiply.

However, at the moment we are absolute beginners with all these new 
possibilities.  We dont know what they are and we dont know how to use them. 
  I think the only way to improve this situation is to initiate a systematic 
inquiry into the whole field of isolating structure.  What we need, in line 
with both TG grammar and Popperian theory, is a device which generates all 
and only the possible morphology-free grammars of a language which must 
express a given set of semantic/grammatical ideas.  In fact, what we would 
probably do is decide what set of ideas we want to be able to express in an 
IAL, and base the device on that set.  I dont think it would be too hard to 
decide on a working set of ideas to be expressed.

I would like to know what people think of this idea.  If people think it is 
worth doing, then I suggest a similar procedure to that which led to the 
Basis Project: first set up a list for preliminary discussions on isolating 
grammar and the idea of a theory, and then, if possible, start an open 
project on the same list to develop the theory I propose.  How about Project 
Isola?

Kordiale, James Chandler
idojc{at}hotmail{dot}com

http://www.geocities.com/idojc/yindex.html - Ido index

> distinctive ending for each part of speech in order to clarify which is the 
> noun, which is the verb etc. in a Glosa sentence.  The fact that people are 
> having recourse to such devices really demonstrates the lack of any kind of

Charles sometimes suggests modifying the last letter to indicate part of
speech. As far as I know, no other Glosa-pe like that idea. Most
Glosa-pe seem happy not having clear flags for parts of speech, and
relying on intuitive interpretation.

Personally, I want simple markers to indicate the start of the "Verb
Phrase" and the start of the "Direct Object Phrase". In my own language
(Glo), which is still about 90% compatible with Glosa, I am
experimenting with 'ca' and 'da', respectively.  I tried 'nu' and 'du'
as VP markers, but they just didn't work well. And I'm not satisfied
with u/plu for noun marking for a variety of reasons that I can share if
you really care.

> I would like to know what people think of this idea.  If people think it is

I would probably participate, although I'm a bit skeptical about what
might come out of it.

the 'ge' fore and aft muddles things up - let's take an english sentence

a statement='a sentence does get written/write by me' the statement occured 
at 2022 hours 12/8/02
'me' existed before then and is time 1
the uttering of the statement occured at 2033 etc
the sentence was in existence after 2022
so, front phrase has number and= 'I', the mid phrase has time and = 'am 
writing/write'
the back phrase has number and = 'the sentence'
but I want to swap the phrase order round so the front phrase= 'the sentence' 

the mid phrase = 'does get written'   -   'get' tells us that the phrase 
order is not usual
the back phrase= .by me'   -   the by also telld us that the order is 
different
so,       [FP] u frasi [MP] du gene grafo [BP] per mi

in my style of G, prose we have FP + MP + BP + [BP]   
or        FP + MP and gene + BP and per
following some suggestions I could use       em/da u frasi du gene grafo per 
mi

new terminology to avoid jargon

From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com

I noticed that Rick Morneau has finally HTMLized his monumental
"design document" Lexical Semantics, and has changed his ontology
in an interesting way. I think it could be borrowed as an outline
to arrange Glosa concept-words. See appendix C (if interested):
http://www.srv.net/~ram/lexical_semantics.html

Another approach is WordNet's hierarchy. They now have a
much nicer interface, though it's still a generation behind
(Tcl/Tk instead of HTML/CGI). And it's a 12mb download:
http://www.cogsci.princeton.edu/~wn/

In each case, the nouns are more relevant to Glosa vocab
selection than are the verbs/etc.

'mi du face on urba piktu' and that the FP corresponds to the BF - switch the 
phrases round
face - MP head/ MP helpw
ex - could be BP intro/ MP help intro word
mi - could be BP head/ MP helpw 
 . - mi is BP head or  MP help

'ge; un ax urba piktu du face ex mi'

ge - FP exchanged for BP so sentence = [FP]mi [MP]du face [BP]un ax urba 
piktu
un - [BP] intro
ax - help w follows
urba [BP helpw]
piktu [BP] head
du MP intro
piktu MP head
ex [ indicates FP follows]
mi - [FP]   

something like the second sentence is easier for me to sort out but mauls 
glosa somewhat

I think about it quite differently. For me, ~gene~ is very intimately
connected to the "verb" itself. ~gene face~ is almost like a single word
for me--it is certainly a single concept. The inverted form of "to make"
is "to be made". I don't think of it in terms of shifting phrases
around.

Moving the ~gene~ (or ~ge~) away from the verb makes it VERY difficult
for me to understand the sentence.

Kevin

I compiled the "Glosa Basic Reference" which first went up on the world
wide web several years ago.  Ron Clark and Wendy Ashby approved it.  In
the "GBR" 'ne' is "not" and 'no-' forms opposites.  Without going back
to look, I don't know whether these are the ways things are defined in
other G.E.O. publications or not.  One thing that was awkward when I
got interested in Glosa some years ago was some inconsistency in
publications.

From: "James Chandler" <idojc{at}hotmail{dot}com>
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 2002 15:22:12 +0000
Cc: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au

The following passage may throw some light on the debate about how/whether 
to mark PoS in an isolating language:

Because Vietnamese does not use inflectional morphology to distinguish 
different parts of speech, it is sometimes difficult to determine whether a 
given item is a verb, noun or adjective, apart from its syntactic context. 
This has led some researchers to claim that such form-class distinctions are 
purely functionally-determined in Vietnamese (and other isolating 
languages); that is, the label of a particular item is entirely a function 
of its syntactic distribution. A more extreme version of this argument is 
the claim that form-class distinctions drawn from IndoEuropean languages, 
for example, the distinction between verbs and adjective, are inapplicable 
to isolating languages. To counter such claims, the task of the universalist 
is to find evidence that distinguishes proposed form-classes independently 
of their syntactic distribution.

This is from the Vietnamese Grammar Project reference grammar, section 4.1:

http://www.arts.mcgill.ca/programs/linguistics/projects/Vietnamese/VGP/toc.htm

Interesting stuff.

I require some information on which moods are expressible in the languages 
which I am not an expert on: LsF, Glosa, Interlingua, Occidental.

In Esp and Ido, conditional is expressed by -us, and imperative, optative 
and hortative by -u/-ez:  me vidus, videz!, li videz!, ni videz!

In Novial, conditional is by vud, imperative by the simple ground form, 
optative by mey, and hortative by let:  me vud vida, vida!, mey les vida!,

> In fact, I have ear-marked some of my September
> holiday to producing a Glosa 2500 Learner's Vocabulary

Occidental has such a vocabulary. I have found it to be a
frustration, a hindrance, no help at all. The learner will
be unable to find what he wants, and then grow weary of
coining new compounds for common notions; amateur etymologists
are not easy to train. It would be far better to have a
complete and comprehensive word list, and if possible there
should also be a good-enough translation program available
on the web. Only then will we see any significant number
of people writing in Glosa, and only then will people have
much chance of understanding that which gets posted.

    I do not agree.  I think that Hogben showed, with the original
Interglossa, that a carefully chosen vocabulary can be operated well. 
The key, as I see it, is to know the vocabulary thoroughly, so that one
is at home in it, so to speak.  The Voice of America, as I recall,
makes international radio broadcasts in a limited vocabulary, Special
English I think it is called, of around 2000 words, apart from proper
names (and, presumably, the residual inflected forms that English has).
