At 03:51 PM 11/8/02 EST, Sid wrote:
>agree about the capitals and wrote as much some time ago - i tend to leave 
>them out in glosa, some europeanophiles are not happy but hindi for instance 
>does without them happily. i am working on the assumption that the glosa
rule 
>is no caps but they can be used if required and in any way that people  want
>i did toy with making a sort of tutorial whereby there was a story and each 
>sentence's grammar, vocab etc was explained. however the attitude to grammar 
>was rather confused
>   .....
*    Hello Sid and All,
     While Sid sees capitals, and, I suspect, fullstops, as optional extras
in Glosa, I do not.
     Firstly, hindi users of Glosa - I have not met any yet - might choose
to optionally avoid the use of capital letters and most punctuation, but
the downside of this could be that many Glosa-pe will not attempt to read
what they have written.
     Secondly, with a syntax-based grammar system, I feel that Glosa needs
all the legitimate help it can get.  In fact, it is my considered belief
that punctuation is a part of Glosa grammar, acting as sign-posts to the
start and finish of the various elements of sentences.
     Thirdly, Capitals have to main functions, in Glosa, as I see it: they
denote the start of a new sentence; and they indicate the presence of a
proper noun - a particular person or place.
      mi fe-fili gina pa dice qestio qe id du pluvi     .......... (1)
  OR
      Mi fe-fili, Gina, pa dice qestio, ~Qe, id du pluvi?~.   .... (2)

    I suspect that each of thes sentences could be marked, with points
accumulating for ambiguity/lack_of_clarity, and I feel that the former
version would show a greater mandicap rating than the latter.
    While the writer of 1. would know where to pause, and where to put
vocal stress, when he read it out, someone else handed the message might
have to think for a while before he could understand the message - as he
thought the writer intended it.
    Someone reading 2. as an 'unseen', on the other hand, has twelve
additional cues to the structure, semantics and unusual components of the
sentence, and could read it with suitable pauses and vocal stress,
directly, by making use of these non-alphanumeric clues.

    Sid, I, for one, find the reading of your posts difficult, because of
the lack of signposts to their structure.

    If you are conducting an experiment, what is its hypothesis, how do you
test it, and when do you know that the hypotesis has been disproved?

    Fashions in language come and go, and some just keep coming.  At
present, the smart young things are leaving out increasing numbers of
commas from their writing.
    I predict that there will ultimately be a swing against this trend ..
when grammar is again taught in our schools.  I am not sure how many
generations will get lost in the wilderness of stream_of_consciousness-type
writing before the cry goes up - for greater clarity in the structure of
prose; things could get a lot worse, before they start getting better.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

*   Maybe so.
    But, I know Ron had the capacity to work at Genius level, and I also
know that I do not.  So, I fear that further years spent in trying to
derive a different formulation, based on present Glosa, and forming a
superior language from it - much as Ron derived Glosa from Interglossa -
would end with me dead, as well, also not seeing the full fruition of the
new form I had created.

    I see my role more as a Beta Tester of Glosa, and not as that of a
co-creator of the world's best 'syntax-based' language.  During the time
that I was Alpha Testing Glossa/Glosa (1982 - 1992) I had a pretty bumpy
ride.  Since entering the Beta Testing phase, I have felt much happier,
there having been many fewer changes.

    Personally, I have not enough room in my life, nor years up my sleeve,
to go through a phase of Alpha Testing, again.  And, if we look at the
progress made, up til now, on the Glosalist, we could predict a very slow
speed of progress, if people were asked to go back to basics, and start
again, with some New Millenium Glosa.
    Ron Clark, after working with Interglossa for about four year, did,
around 1976, clear the slate, and start again - with a revision and
simplification of  Hogben's "outline" of an auxillary language.

    However, it does test my imagination .. to the limit .. to try to push
the basic framework of Glosa(Clark/Ashby, 1992) into a better shape than it
is already.  Agreed, the refinements of vocabulary are calling, and a
clear, simple statement of Glosa's grammar would help, but these are
peripheral to the language's specification, which seems pretty damned good.

    My guess, is, that with urging from Walter and Carmelo, Glosa is due to
take a step forward, not backwards, into Gamma testing.  I welcome this,
and will do my best to trim around the edges, of any ragged pieces
remaining from the Beta Testing phase.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

more a "language for science - that can be spoken by the common man, as well."
   And here's a neat concept: recall the teaching of Scientific French and
Scientific Russian, etc; now, imagine that instead of Russian or French
joining words between the scientific terminology, you stick "glue words"
from the same (Greko-Latin) source as the terminology;  you end up with
something that can be called Scientific Scientific.

   Needless to say such a streamlined, simplified language needs a grammar:
Ron Clark, the prime author chose the logical structure of English sentence
construction, but got rid of the five inflections in English, and created a
grammar which is 'syntax-based.'  Recall how computer programming languages
always go on about their syntax - but never about their 'inflections.'  He
thought the language was so simple, obvious and logical that he avoided
publishing a Glosa Grammar: he said the mind sorted it out intuitively; it
is possible that, in this, he over-estimated human capabilities.

*  Sorry about the irrational fear.
   Most of the early terms from science are derived from Latin; though,
now, Greek is proving more useful.
   The original word stem is called Indo-European: both Greek and Latin
come from this; and I simplify the phrase "Greek and Latin roots" to saying
"the Classical roots of science."

>I never used the esperanto interactive tutorials (OK, so I did, but
>not the interactive element); I would welcome friendly glosa intro

>dictionary-grepper and a translated fairy-tale (If anyone wants to
>write/translate fairy tales or similar literature, I'd love it!).
>
*  Glad to hear Eo has modern instructional materials.
   Yes Glosa urgently needs multimedia instruction .. as well as good B&W
laser printable instruction, as well.
   Funny you shold mention fairy tales; I did over Three bears, Red Riding
Hood and Cinderella in historical time; these archival items are still on
my website (probaly needing a little editing to update their language usage).
   I intend, in about a month, to get started with Flash MX; however, your
computer skills sound a lot better than mine.  Please stick around: we
probably can use you. 
 
Only Kidding,

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] vocabulary cleanup
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 01:43:15 -0800

I've generated a vocabulary of 6730 words from several
international public-domain sources, including the
combined Glosa list, Ido/Novial, the Romance languages,
and a few others. The algorithm is impartial and
reproducible, and capable of improvement and updating.

All words conform to the easily-pronounced bisyllabic
consonant-vowel pattern, resembling the "scientific
combining forms" in ease of compounding, yet still
remain somewhat recognizable or at least plausible
at-first-sight to Romance speakers.

While not "perfect" or "final", this appears much
more attractive and practical than the current
Glosa vocabulary. I think it would be a good basis
for the necessary Glosa reforms. It is even possible
to write tolerable pidginesque text by using it
experimentally without any grammatical particles.

If anyone here is interested. In the last world-war
most interest in IALs died; looks like a repeat now.

dear Robin and all
Robin asks me if I am experimenting, yes, and investigating too. I have been 
a glosa-pe for about 30 years [an esperanto person for about half an hour]. 
if I had not thought highly of G, I would have left it long ago, however, I 
think that like everything else in the world, there are shortcomings and it 
is these that I am looking at. also I was in touch with hindi and similar 
languages while i was teaching and helping boys from southern asia.
my views on full stops seem to be misunderstood rather. If I were 
[hand]writing in G or any other language with the roman alphabet and could 
keep my writing legible, i would make the dot at the end of a sentence 
largish and slightly far away from the last letter. no problems in seeing it 
and it works perfectly adequately.
however in some type fonts the dot is tiny and put next to the last 'd'. as 
far as i am concerned the dot is invisible and looks like part of the 
squiggly bit at the end of the letter [serif]. i just can't see it! This 
seems to have been noticed long, long ago. Instead of doing something about 
the dot, it has been decide to make the following letter a capital. now we 
have to learn 52 letters instead of 26 and we have the end doubly and 
redundantly marked!

>So hello there and are you telling me that this is a new language ...if so 
>let me know the name and where i can find it...until then bye.

*Hi to Rob Harris and others New to Glosa.
   Hearing Glosa spoken will be difficult.
   It is Old and New: It is as old as the Indo-European (proto-Aryian) root
stock; it watches as this bifurcates into Greek and Latin; then it draws
the threads together into what remains of the Greek and Latin roots - as
represented in modern science.
   So, Glosa is a synthesis of the very old with the usage of the rather new.
   Sounds like Italian.
   Sentence formation with the structures of English.
   Words are concept centres, rather than concrete objects.
   So, Glosa words, from the Classical languages, are shorn of their
inflectional endings, and represent ideas.
   They are used, within reason, to function as any Part-of-Speech.
   The intepretation of a word's function is given by its place in the
phrase or clause: SYNTAX is the grammar engine of Glosa.
   Oh yes, there's one rule: a word is modified by its precedent(s).
Modifiers precede the word they modify.  And while it is somewhat
misleading to use the categories of 'adjective' and 'adverb', it is still
handy to think in terms of the traditional functions within a sentence.

   U tako bruno vulpes salta supra u laxa kanis.
                      |           |
            S         |     V     |      O

  
     quick brown fox    jumps over    lazy dog 
                |            |             |
      modifiers | N       V  | ^      mod. | N
                               |
                              Verb 
                            Auxilliary 
                      |             |
                      |Compound verb|

   Yet Glosa is not "relexified English".
   Good Glosa 'maps onto' English, BUT English does not automatically 'map
onto' Glosa.

   Glosa users are spread so widely that they are too far away from one
another to hear each other: there are also some problems with the mechanics
of sound files on the Net; and, at the start, Glosa users needs to think
about the words they will use - this can slow down speech, for learners.
In Glosa we ought to use the correct concept rather than slip into
metaphor.  National-language idiomatic usage would be too confusing
altogether.

   Of the national languages, English might be the closest to Glosa in that
it has only five inflected endings, and has a background in both Greek and
Latin.  Also, the SVO order, and the structure of phrases and their
combination into clauses, in English, is considered, by some, to have the
most logical of constructions, and to allow the widest expression of
meanings.  Of course, among the highly inflected languages terribly fine
shades of meaning are possible, EG Russian; Glosa, having NO inflections
benefits greatly from economy of form, but relies on the juxtaposition of
words for its precision.

   What is also similar between English and Glosa is that the
(syntax-based) grammar is more intuitive than proscribed.  Nobody stood up
one day, and said, "Listen here, this is how the syntax of English is going
to go."
   It is claimed that the language sense is hard-wired into our brains, and
that this relies primarily on word order (syntax).  So, while every
language that is spoken is used more or less intuitively, English (and
Glosa) with little (or no) inflections, could work more closely to the way
our brains are 'hard-wired' to work than do the lanuages that are more
inflected. 
  
   With the way things are going on the international scene, we might even
have to wait for civilisation to come around again, before Glosa is heard
on broadcast media.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

Sid wrote:

> thinking of using roget's thesaurus. first 85 or so syllables of m.l. would
> point to 85 main divisions of the thesurus the next to the  subdivisions.
> 'bababa' abstract/nouns, existence,esse,=being etc

I like that idea for several reasons, but it's difficult to do right.
Glosa itself has a basic word-list drawn from Roget. Today there are
other (more scientific) multi-lingual lists, such as EuroWordNet,
which better dissect(s) the top levels of an appropriate "ontology".

A language called "Ro" made 100 top-level divisions, each assigned
to a consonant-vowel pair as you suggest, and these included also the
grammatical necessities such as noun verb etc. There is a good web page
for Ro somewhere under Jeffrey Henning's http://langmaker.com ...
Subdivisions used only 1 letter apiece, completely arbitrarily.

Natural languages have better and easier ways to achieve derivation.
For an auxiliary language, there is extreme pressure to simplify.
The most flexible way is just to word-compound. Tunu is a modern
conlang/auxlang that has only 1500 CVCV-type roots (e.g. "babu")
but systematically derives all the words in several basic-English
word-lists by CVCV-CVCV compounding (e.g. "babu-fufa"). Such a
language would be the easiest for a global (non-euro) audience.

The universal human linguistic tendency is to evolve roots toward
bisyllabic CVCV, and then erode the highest usage/frequency ones
into CV particles (which may be pre- or post-positioned, and may
become affixed to roots). There was a euro-based interlingua spoken
all around the Mediterranean for 800 years called "Lingua Franca"
that followed this pattern, and Glosa should emulate it.

If it is acceptable to sacrifice euro-recognizability, then the
required modifications to G can be very few and nearly painless.
"Supo la perde di reco a Euro, impli la recui cambi di G i posi
poco, anci cuasi manca pena". Or something kinda like that.

Here are extracts from PGN87 perhaps for a projected tutorial. It is probably 
more useful to become at ease with translating from Glosa to English or other 
tongue befare doing much into Glosa. We need pieces of Glosa that are 
actually in use rather than purpose built examples and we need to get clear 
the structures of the sentences. There has been a tendency in English and in 
Glosa to shrink away from grammar. Earlier in tutors one was given long lists 
and tables especially of irregularities. Here is the first sentence in this 
PGN, my apologies to its author for not asking permission.

[alphabet and sounds can be inserted later]

'Tem pre oligo meno plu nova-papira-pe e komerci-pe pa dice de u ski de plu 
lingua in Englanda.' 

 [EXTRA PHRASE(time)  while before few months  [Tem pre oligo meno] = a few 
months ago    
SUBJECT      some newspaper-people and commerce-people   [plu nova-papira-pe 
e komerci-pe]
VERB         did speak   [pa dice] 
OBJECT       of the know   [de u ski]
             of the languages   [de plu lingua]
             in England  [in Englanda]

introducing words:- 'plu'/some introduces the subject noun phrase
'did' introduces the verb phrase
'of the' introduces the object phrase
'while before' introduces the extra phrase of time

'people' are the two head words in the subject phrase
'speak' is the head word in the verb phrase
'know' is the head of the object
'months' is the head of the extra phrase

'newspaper'/'commerce' modify [ help/clarify/add to the meaning of] 'people'
'of the languages' modifies 'know'
'in England' modifies 'languages'
EXTRA modifies the verb phrase
'few' introduces months [a noun phrase inside an extra phrase]

sid

Here there are some questions I asked Wendy Ashby and her answers.
Sorry, I am late, my letter was from May the 5th and her from June
the 3rd.  The questions mainly belong to Glosalist discussions in the
first half of the year 2002.

Mi volu; vi habe hedo Kristo-nati-tem, boni fini de paleo anua e
sani, paci e boni-fortuna 2003!  Marcel.


-----------------------------------------------------------

Possessive Pronoun
==================

In inter-reti na diskusi de u loka de "possessive pronoun".

In classical Glosa the possessive pronoun seems to come before
u(n)/plu:  mi plu vagona - my cars.  Some people in internet (me too)
rather would like to put it after it.

Advantages:
- It would be more regular.  A noun phrase then always would start
  with a (mandatory) u(n)/plu, the main concept word (noun) comes last
  and all attributes - adjectives, genitives, participles and also the
  possessive pronoun - would come between.
- A noun phrase could be easier acknowledged, when it starts with
  u(n)/plu.
- Appositions: "Mi ne amo plu vi simi - I do not like your apes." /
  "... vi plu simi - ... you apes"

Nick contradicts with the example "u fe bovi - a (female) cow,
fe u bovi - her cow", but this does not convince me (could be
"fe-bovi").  Also I do not think, that there could be confusions with
u-mi, u-tu etc.

Perhaps you can explain, why it must (or only should?) be like this?

 - - - - -

WA: "vi plu simi".  Plu kron "plu" es no-nece.  "vi" es ma de mo.
    "vi simi" es sati.
    Hogben e Ron pa uti "plu tu simi" = your apes (mo persona e ma de
    mo simi).
    Si konfusi es posi Hogben e Ron pa uti "plu simi de tu".  Mu ma
    amo u-ci kausa "plu" veni imedia pre "simi".  Na zero kron pa dice
    de muta u-ci sistema.
    Freqe "u/un" e "plu" es no-nece.  Exempla:
    mo bibli -, tri bibli -, poli bibli -, oligo bibli -, zero bibli
    es epi tabla.

    Fe-bovi = cow, female ox
    bovi-fe = cow-girl
    fe bovi alo bovi de fe = her cow.
    Pende itera ex kontextu e metro de exakti info es nece.  Hogben
    ma amo uti exakti "bovi de fe".  Sed in tako dice e grafo, poli-pe
    ma amo uti "fe bovi".  Na (Ron e mi) pa amo un exakti de plu frase
    de Hogben kausa mu evita ero translati; anti-co tem uti ma longi
    frase in tako dice e tako grafo plu persona freqe ma amo brevi id
    e evita "de" etc.

[I find this question very important!!!  I understood,
  "'u(n)/plu' - possessive pronoun - noun"
is okay, but prefereable, if the sentence is not too long, is
  "'u(n)/plu' - noun - 'de' - possessive pronoun".]
-----------------------------------------------------------

sto
===

Mi pa diskusi ko Nick Hempshall de frase
  "Mi ne pote ne ridi - I couldn't help laughing".
Nick pa ma amo "Mi ne pote sto-se ridi"; kausa an ne amo bi "ne" in mo
frase.
Mi pa doxo; id habe difere
  "couldn't help" = "couldn't suppress" = "alexi proto"
e
  "sto" = "stop" = "fini" ridi.
Po-co Nick grafo; "sto - suppress; prevent" es in inter-reti
verba-lista.  E an habe veri.  Plu-ci semani veni ex bibli
"Central Glosa":  "sto - suppress" p. 119, e "sto - prevent" p. 108.
Mi doxo; "sto - suppress, prevent" ne es boni.  Id sio es ma boni; si
na sio habe "suppress" = supresi alo 1000 alexi e
"prevent" - preventi, profilakti alo 1000 kura pre e
"sto" solo "stop, halt, ...". Qe, tu doxo qo-ra?

 - - - - -

WA: "mi ne pote sto se ridi" es in Interglossa e "18 Steps".
    Alexi es "protect, defend".  Posi ne gru ci.
    Si tu ne amo "sto" posi tu ma amo:
      "tena se" = restrain myself
      alo "resista se" = resist myself.

[I understood, that "sto" does not make a difference, whether the
action to be stopped or prevented has already started or not.
Supplemented in Glosa Inter-reti Diktionaria:
"resista se 1  resist oneself" item added.
"tena se 1  restrain oneself" item added.]
-----------------------------------------------------------

orange
======

"orange": qe id semani solo u frukti alo plus kroma "rubi-xanto"?

 - - - - -

WA: "orange" in Interglossa e Glosa 6000 = frukti e kroma.
    Hogben pa grafo "mi elekti orange kausa de id lati internatio uti
    in komerci."
    Glosa 1000 = kroma es "rubi-xanto".

[In Glosa Inter-reti Diktionaria:
"orange {French} 1++  orange {fruit}" unchanged.
"rubi-xanto 1++  orange {colour}" unchanged.
"orange {French}  orange {colour}" item added.]
-----------------------------------------------------------

kamera
======

"kamera": qe id semani solo "room" alo plus fotografi-me?

 - - - - -

WA: Fotografo-me + kamera = camera.
    Plu proto fotografi-me pa es "pusi kamera".

[Typical: one line fotografO-me, then fotografI-me.
-i is prefereable, because photography is an international word.
In Glosa Inter-reti Diktionaria:
"fotografi-me 1+*  camera {apparatus}" removed "*".
"kamera 1++  accomodate; apartment; camera {room}; chamber; hall; room"
  added meaning "camera {apparatus}".]
-----------------------------------------------------------

valid
=====

Qo es Glosa verba pro "valid"?

 - - - - -

WA: validi = valid, strong, sound.

[In Glosa Inter-reti Diktionaria:
"validi +  sound {well}; strong" added meaning "valid".]
-----------------------------------------------------------

solidarity
==========

Qo es Glosa verba pro "solidarity" e "solidary"?  Qe, posi "solidari"
alo in 1000 simpli "akorda"?

WA: Pende ex kontextu, exampla: tu pote uti
      komuni akorda
      lega akorda, etc.

    Solidarity es FranÃ§ais lexi.  Itera kontextu es gravi.
    Plu exempla:
      komuni akti
      kon ergo
      ergo kon alelo ko komuni fide

[Unfortunately no direct "solidarity".
In Glosa Inter-reti Diktionaria:
"komuni akorda  solidarity; solidary" item added.
"lega akorda  solidarity; solidary" item added.
"komuni akti  solidarity; solidary" item added.
"kon ergo  solidarity; solidary" item added.
"komuni fide  solidarity; solidary" item added.]

> Sorry, I am late, my letter was from May the 5th and her from June

I am used to Latin-American time, which runs 3 hours late,
but this 6 month lag is truly impressive ...

> WA: "vi plu simi".

> Si konfusi es posi Hogben e Ron pa uti "plu simi de tu".
> Mu ma amo u-ci kausa "plu" veni imedia pre "simi".

> plu persona freqe ma amo brevi id e evita "de" etc.

She is correct in placement of the possessive/genitive.
Here you have 2 noun phrases combined with or without a
particle. Each can be singular or plural, independently.
Clearest usage invokes the particle DE (and/or SU) to
separate the possessor from the possessed, but in the
real-world, people often elide it, leaving ambiguity.
So "tu simi" could be either insulting or not depending
on context; re-inserting a SU or ES would disambiguate.
(SU is just my suggestion for a new particle to be the
reverse of DE, i.e. the so-called Saxon genitive.)
But she suggests "fe bovi" as a natural elision; most
of the world would prefer "bovi fe" (from elided DE).

> Si tu ne amo "sto" posi tu ma amo:
> "tena se" = restrain myself

I consider the STI and STO of Hogben completely bogus.
TENA is better, but then I'd want 100% bisyllabic roots.
(Words like KONFUSI and IMEDIA also appear bogus to me.)
The truest Glosa has a self-consistency beyond authority.

'St. Lucia es u landa in orienta Karibean Mari.'

SUBJECT St. Lucia [St. Lucia]
VERB is [es]
OBJECT a land [u landa]
   in east Caribean Sea [in orienta Karibean Mari.]

capital S denotes beginning of sentence also, here, a name [an island]; 
capitals L, K, M denote names [an island and a sea]. Because it is a name and 
therefore a noun there is only one being refered to so no number is needed to 
introduce the phrases
In glosa, a word can be verb, noun etc. In this sentence, 'es' is unlikely to 
be anything but a verb so it is easy to decide which is subject and which is 
objekt.


'Id tegu 620 qadra kilometri.' 
 SUBJECT[S] it [Id]
VERB[V] cover [tegu]
OBJECT[O] 620 square kilometre [620 qadra kilometri]

'tegu' could be 'the cover', 'to cover', 'the covered object'but as it 
imediately follows the pronoun 'id', it must be the verb.

a parallel investigation into the developing of munada linugu



SG
'Tem pre oligo meno plu nova-papira-pe e komerci-pe pa dice de u ski de plu 
lingua in Englanda.'

ml:-
'teme pere oligo meno, lu pe-papira-nova e pe-komerici pa dice de u siki de 
lu linugu in Enege-lanada - ' 

here the head  word [oligo, pe, dice] follows the intro word  [teme, pere, lu 
pa u] and a word is modified by the word after it. this is completely 
different from glosa but it makes it much easier to find the head.
the comma indicates that the previous phrase is EXTRA and that the next is 
SUBJECT
all letters are pronounced as in the international phonetic alphabet.

I have a copy of roget so i shall do some maths with it.
there are the consonants:- b[0] c[1] d[2] f[3] g[4] j[5] k[6] l[7] m[8] n[9] 
p[10] r[11] s[12] t[13] v[14] x[15] z[16] and the 5vowels aeiou [0 to 4]. 
this makes 85 CV syllables.

if we look up 'world-wide' in roget's index, we get 3 sections, i choose 
'universal' which is section 79. counting the items that are apropriate,    
'world-wide' is number 81 [my maths may be askew but my argument will be 
demonstrated]
divide the section number by the number of CV syllables:- 79/85=0 + remainder 
79
same with item number:- 81/85=0+81
divide the 79 by 5 [syllables ba, be, bi, bo, bu, ca, ce,  etc], we get 14 
consonants remainder 4 = vowels. result ='vu'  add'-'
0/5+0=0; syllable 0='ba' add to the others:- vu-ba
81/5=16+rem1:- ze so 'world-wide becomes 'vu-baze [put the stress on the 
vowel before the '-'.
'language' is section 557 first item [ignore], 
557/85 gives 6 rem 43
6/5 gives 1 rem 1 i.e. 'ce'
43 gives 8 rem 3,      'mo'
'cemo' stress on last syllable
'worldwide language' = 'vu-baze cemo'

[this is a reply to 2 messages, saving virtual paper]

> VERB is [es]

I feel that Glosa is the auxlang for people who hate grammar.
To satisfy them most deeply, I propose the elimination of verbs
and adjectives, etc, leaving only "plain words" (of 2 syllables
or maybe more) and "magic words" (1 syllable only). Words like
is/have/do are "magic" and we never need to spook the potential
clients by use of that intimidating V-word.

> SUBJECT[S] it [Id]
> VERB[V] cover [tegu]
> OBJECT[O] 620 square kilometre [620 qadra kilometri]

I expected "has" instead of "cover". All simple sentences can be
recast to use one of a dozen or so magic auxiliaries instead of
troublesome iffy verbs like "cover".

> and a word is modified by the word after it. this is completely
> different from glosa but it makes it much easier to find the head.

There are 2 problems here (adjectives, compounds) that seem
like 1 (modifiers), and they need different solutions.

True adjectives as in English are not common in other languages,
most either are treated as verbs (e.g. Japanese) or nouns (Latin).
It is possible to allow either word order without chaos:
"white house" = "casa blanca" = "blanca casa" = "house white".
When it becomes necessary to precise the meaning further,
magic words like DE/A/EX restore order within the phrase.

Compound words are the tougher problem, because we really need
to declare for one order or the other. Especially if the vocab
is reduced to approx 5000 CVCV roots, compounding must generate
most of the 50000 or so real-world words in the full lexicon.
I don't know which is best -- but "blancacasa" sounds silly.
Maybe the answer is just to forbid such compounds?

For a good sample of these things see the Kalatunu web page,
wherever that has wandered off to ... or for a bad example,
http://catty.com/~catty/lang/tomato.htm (apologies in advance).

> his letter with web sites addresses seems to be lost

It's in the archives of that Ailanto Kafejo fellow.
Anyway you can find anything at google.com ...

> divide the section number by the number of CV syllables

I have several different Roget's from used book sales.
One has a numerical scheme that goes like:

EPIDEMIC, as in
	plague 85.5
	contagious 85.61
	prevalent 863.12
	plentiful 990.7

So all we need are 11 consonants and 11 vowels ...

In original Roget's there were around 1000 major
headings which grouped all words, so a CVC pattern
could handle them all comfortably (20 * 5 * 20 = 2000).

Or we could use the sorted-by-frequency BNC list:
1=the 2=of ... 996=president 997=house ... 199997=horsefly

More seriously, the EuroWordNet project identified a good
base set of word-concepts shared by most euro langs.

I have generated a list of English words translated by
multi-lingual dictionaries; if they don't appear there,
they must not be important ... Here are the FAM- entries
above level 11, higher number indicating higher frequency:

35      fame
15      famed
16      familial
27      familiar
17      familiarity
15      familiarization
16      familiarize
15      familiarized
15      familiarizes
15      familiarizing
12      familiarly
17      families
35      family
27      famine
12      famines
15      famish
12      famished
35      famous
12      famously

I think this implies the need for FAME, FAMILY, FAMINE
and maybe FAMILIAR in any plausible auxlang's base vocab.

*  Saluta holo-vi, e speciali Tom,
     1. Il es u problema ko duce plu verbi intra plu England-lingua frasa.
Te salta ad u ma latu grada, de traduce u spiritu de tu origi textu, tu
nece skope in u semani de tu origi England-lingua frasa.
  Poli tem uno-pe gene kapti ex plu idioma e metafera de English-lingua.
Plura-tem, il es u ma bono mode de expresi un idea de u-la; qi gene ge-uti
intra un England-lingua frasa.
  Mi dona, ad u-ci koncepa, u nima 'kogita uti Glosa.'  Si tu qestio-auto,
'qod mi tenta dice, ci?' tu cerka u semani poste plu verbi. Kron tu grafo
uti Glosa, sine traduce, tu pote uti simpli struktura ko tu frasa, e debi
sio kogita direkto uti Glosa.  U-ci mode de grafo Glosa evita u nece de
traduce ex England-lingua.
     2. Us nuli de turba concerne mi nima: tu pa fatiga, kron tu grafo; mi
solo problema, mi ne logi de qo-pe tu grafo.  U pisci histori uti poesi,
sed u-ci es u dificili forma pro plu gene-sco-pe.
  Tu detekti u-ci faktu ex tu praxi mero.  Mi sugeri ke tu praxi ko prosi
te gene un este de u lingua, pre tu tenta grafo in poesi.
     3.Plu ero:-
 na [=us, we]  ... ne [not], nuli [nothing, no, none], no [un-, dis]
        a, ad [to, towards]  ... de [of, about, to]  te [in order to]
     4.Plu qestio:-
        to u proto de u frasa, tu pote uti u capitala litera.
        To u proto de u frasa, tu pote uti u capitala litera.
 
        Feli sedi epi tapeta.   ... U-ci dona semani, sed id soni
                                          primitivi.
        U feli sedi epi u tapeta.  .. Plu nima-verbi marka, "u," dona 
                                         civilisa ad u-ci frasa.

        ... X; qi ....        relativi pro-nima
          
   il es  [there is]   IL eqa u forma verbi: id kompleti u sintaxi.  

Posi traduce:
   Il es nuli nomi - infra qi ali mero de u-ci universa gene ge-
regula; qi ne gene implika intra u kemi histori de u kandela.  Il 
es nuli ma boni porta dia qi uno-pe pote ki in u studi de skience hetero de
u kura puta de u fisika feno de u kandela.

  Without actually having studied Glosa, you have done exceedingly well, Tom.
  Beware of word-for-word translation, in that English-language metaphors
and idioms can be translated unthinkingly.
  While the above original paragraph is good poetry and also a profound
thought, translation of such imaginitive language was not the original
intention for Glosa.  And, while I was going to do a pedrestrian version of
the passage, I thought better of it.
  The fact remains that Glosa was put forward originally as a language for
science; and it was intended for direct communication of fact.

  The version I did is more plodding than your leaner version, Tom, but it
has more "T"s crossed and "I"s dotted.
  So, I strongly reccommend trying a few straight sentences first, before
^going out on a limb^ into poetry.
  While Glosa is highly suitable for poetry, I suspect that it will be more
like the classical Chinese poetry, where because of the word economy, both
the meaning and the words of a poem will have to be taught.

  You ask about the use of the semi-colon in Glosa.  The authors originally
postulated that, because of the major role of syntax in Glosa's grammar,
and the fact that punctuation becomes even more of an aid to the
understanding of structure in Glosa, than it is in English,  
that it would be useful to indicate the start of phrases and clauses
differently in Glosa.  Commas, in Glosa, as in English, are the logical
choice to indicate the start of phrases; however, to differentiate between
phrases and clauses, it was decided that the semi-colon would indicate the
start of a clause, where this was needed for clear understanding.
  Regardless of the authors' advice, a number of Glosa enthusiasts have
declared the semi-colon to be ugly and unwarranted, so they persist in
using commas to introduce clauses.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

'U duce-urba de u landa es Kastries; e id valuta es un Orienta Karibean 
Dolar.'

SUBJECT[S]  the lead-town of the land [U duce-urba de u landa ]
VERB[V]     is [es]
OBJECT[O]   Kastries

Capital letter at the beginning of the sentence and the name 'Kastries'

JOINING SIGNS 'and', ';' [; e] The semi colon indicates the end of one 
sentence but which is joined to another, 'e' also joins two sentences. 'e' 
can also join words into phrases 'land and sea' so the semicolon can 
distinguish between the two uses.
As the sentence is joined to the one before, a capital is not used.
[S]    its money [id valuta]
[V]    is [es]
[O]    the west carribean dollar [un Orienta Karibean Dolar.]
   ***** Because glosa does not make much distinction between nouns, verbs, 
adjectives etc, slight confusions can arise. As 'id valuta' stands, 'id' 
could be a pronoun and 'valuta' a verb [it cashes .... a cheque]. However, 
the following 'es' makes this very unlikely. in 'U id valuta', 'U' introduces 
a noun phrase so that the 'id' modifies 'valuta' - 'its money' ****

'St. Lucia  pa gene krati 14 kron inter plu France-pe e England-pe pre id pa 
gene libe tem 1979.' 

[S]        St Lucia
[V]       [past tense] got governed  [pa gene krati]
'Pa' introduces the verb and indicates the past tense, 'gene' is the 
equivalent of the English passive.
EXTRA[X]   14 times [14 kron] a time phrase modifting the verb phrase.
[O]        between French people and English people [plu France-pe e 
England-pe]
JOINING WORD  pre [before] joins the main sentence above to the one following
[S]          id [it]    no capital
[V]          got liberated  [pa gene libe]
[X]          in 1979 [tem 1979], a time phrase

As/to a would-be creator/inventor/discoverer of language:

You can start with just the roots in a jargon/pidgin stage
like the Chinook Jargon (see the wonderful web site of
Tenas Wawa, somewhere under geocities.com last I looked).
Then you can import a few particles or affixes and get
something more like the Lingua Franca. These were both
real-world, useful auxlangs. And were spoken seriously
by more people than have ever tried Esperanto etc.

The major point to stop forgetting is that an auxlang
must be learned not by children who have the luxury of
100% immersive language brainwashing, but rather by
adults struggling to make a real life who have only a
few hours per week to devote to language study. It had
better not be just a toy language devised imaginatively
but ignorant of linguistic principles, because it won't
work right, and people will drop it just like Glosa etc.

I must admit to losing all hope for Glosa since the
surviving author refuses to either lead or get out
of the way. Nor do I retain any hope that some new
Grand Datuval (see history of Volapuk) will devise
anything better than the 10,000 conlangs already
littering the net (I made one, too) -- none of them
are near good-enough, either. So now it's just English
against the world, later it will be Spanish etc.

You need 3000 to 6000 good short mnemonic roots,
100 particles or affixes, and simple sentence patterns.
Then you must find a bunch of people to agree to use them,
on a continuing, daily basis. Or you just add one more
useless auxlang/conlang/artlang to the trash heap.

Saluta, Charles e holo-vi,
At 01:09 PM 12/26/02 -0800, Charles wrote:
>As/to a would-be creator/inventor/discoverer of language:
>
>You can start with just the roots in a jargon/pidgin stage
>like the Chinook Jargon (see the wonderful web site of
>Tenas Wawa, somewhere under geocities.com last I looked).
>Then you can import a few particles or affixes and get
>something more like the Lingua Franca. These were both
>real-world, useful auxlangs. And were spoken seriously
>by more people than have ever tried Esperanto etc.
>
*  All true about the numbers and the success.  But that was yesteryear.
Now, what is called for is a Nu-speak for the Net.
   Some form of Munda-lingua must eventually emerge for Cyberspace.
   Considering that Spanish is taking over the US, with the infiltration of
all those wet-backs, and that Spanish is easier to learn than English, such
a language could be it.
   If Glosa can be demonstrated to be a regularised language, with
generally international vocabulary ... also with the logical power of
English, it might beat Spanish.  At the present rate of development, there
is no contest.

>The major point to stop forgetting is that an auxlang
>must be learned not by children who have the luxury of
>100% immersive language brainwashing, but rather by
>adults struggling to make a real life who have only a
>few hours per week to devote to language study. 
*  Funny thing, the techology is in place for the high-level teaching of
any language, and Glosa characters have been kept within the normal
keyboard range.
   I do plan to get the Flash MX set-up, when I can find a student who will
let me buy it on their student card.  And yes, the question remains: can
mind-dead executives learn to think in Glosa.
   So, instructional courses pitched at various levels are needed, and for
a while we had a thing going with various groups in Uganda.  The endemic
poverty in that country was both the reason that they responded to our
call, and also the reason for the difficulties we had in supplying them
with materials and equipment.  X = 0
   The other problem that did arise - quite surprisingly to me - was the
reluctance of the would-be Glosa learners to attempt to write in the
language, quite apart from trying to speak in it.
   You could say we had a problem.
   While Glosa appears to follow, and extend, the developmental trend of
the highly successful super-creole, English, it has ended at one extreme of
the linguistic spectrum ... being devoid of inflection.  Now, all national
languages have some inflection, and, while the very heavily inflected,
Latin has bitten the dust, some very popular languages, like Russian, are
extremely strong on inflection, still.  Chinese does stand out as having
unchanging characters. Where have I heard that word "unchanging" before?
   Even though the Chinese could take to Glosa, as the European-like
language whose sentence structure is closest to theirs, I suspect that
'inflection' could be part of the 'hard-wiring of language' built into our
brains.  However, I am convinced that the Universal Grammar, whatever it
is, is primarily Syntax-Based, as is Glosa.

>               It had
>better not be just a toy language devised imaginatively
>but ignorant of linguistic principles, because it won't
>work right, and people will drop it just like Glosa etc.
>
*  Well, do we mean that people have dropped Glosa, or that people would
drop Glosa if they found it to be more of a 'toy language' than a real one?
   Part of my brief is to demonstrate that Glosa is a usable pedestrian
language, suitable for everyday intercommunication, as well as a language
that permits the conveying of exact meaning.
   As I see it, the everyday usage ought to come before the more
complicated employment of Glosa.  I do believe that the structure is sound,
and that the innovation of semantic "inflections" can be effected through a
simple system of compounding.

>I must admit to losing all hope for Glosa since the
>surviving author refuses to either lead or get out
>of the way. 
*  True, Wendy Ashby ought to get over her arthritis or hand the reins on
to someone, or to some group, capable of developing and 'completing' the
language.  A more dynamic leadership, with a definite 'marketing plan'
could do wonders for Glosa.
   Wendy could make a miraculous recovery, and the language could be
completed to the global dissemination stage.  It seems that our prayers are
in order, here.

Nor do I retain any hope that some new
>Grand Datuval (see history of Volapuk) will devise
>anything better than the 10,000 conlangs already
>littering the net (I made one, too) -- none of them
>are near good-enough, either. 
*  I had imagined, long ago, that highly creative people, dissatisfied with
the global mish-mash of language, would have arisen to broaden the Internet
by adding the missing global communication medium to the Net: quel domage.
   It would seem that numbers of science have won, while the qualitative
values of the humanities have lost.

>          So now it's just English
>against the world, later it will be Spanish etc.
>
*  I feel that Charles has misjudged humanity: we are not dead yet.
English is a lovable communication medium, but its patchwork nature does
not suit it to the global learning required for global use.  Another
national language, like Spanish, could succeed where English is failing,
but does Spanish provide sufficient foundation for the next stage of
civilisation?

>You need 3000 to 6000 good short mnemonic roots,
>100 particles or affixes, and simple sentence patterns.
>Then you must find a bunch of people to agree to use them,
>on a continuing, daily basis. Or you just add one more
>useless auxlang/conlang/artlang to the trash heap.
>
*  I am sorry that Charles experience of Interlinguistics has soured his
view.  The numbers above, sound true, though I don't think we need quite so
many particles and affixes - though were we to compile a list of all those
of Glosa, including the generic extensions, we might come close to Charles'
hundred.
   The final cruncher is that human beings are so unbelievably optimistic.
We keep thinking that some bright spark will come along, invent something,
and then all of our problems .. of communication, language, etc .. will be
over.
   The sad part is that when people are sitting on top of the mountain,
they do not realise that they have arrived, and that it is up to them to
plant the flag.  I believe that Glosa needs only a little tweaking - with
no serious change in substance - to flatten  the bumps and smoothe around
the sharp edges.  Some form of administration could be derived to maintain
Wendy's authority, while opening the regulation of the language to a more
vigorous group of trustee/developers.
   But, what is urgently needed is for Glosa-pe to use (or try) the
language.  It was only when I took the plunge, and started converting the
"Three Bears" into Glosa, that I came up against the practical questions
involved in using the language.  I wanted to capture Goldilocks' anguish,
and the bears' sense of loss, as she ran from them: I was not content with
simply telling a story.
   As Ron Clark said to me, twenty-five years ago, "Play with the language."

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

At 03:10 PM 12/26/02 EST, you wrote:
>why bother with grammar?
>when we gradually learn our native tongue we are not given the grammar rules 
>at the beginning. They are there nevertheless and we sort them out to a 
>greater or lesser degree as we go along. why not do the same with Glosa? It 
>is not all that easy and pretty slow. much quicker if it is done for us as 
>soon as possible, appropriately and as one reads. that's what I'm hoping to 
>do.
> 
*  I agree with Sid that Glosa grammar need not be taught as a
pre-requisite to using Glosa, but I feel that properly graded reading
allows the gradual introduction of the various grammatical elements.
   However, some people will demand to know why .. this, and why .. that.
So, if Glosa teaching is based on the hypertext principle, people will be
able to read - taking the grammar 'on trust' - until they find the need to
back-track and check a link from the basic text to its associated
explanation.  This idea makes a story readily accessible to the fast
learner, while giving all of the back-up required for those who need
explanations.

   It's fairly obvious that I am thinking in terms of releasing Glosa
learning materials on CDs using HTML coding.  For the non-Net versions, the
explanations would, I imagine, be better on the adjoining page, rather
than, serially, throughout the text.

*** One request from me to Sid: please bring in your right margin; this
allows for the inevitable expansion of text that follows addition of the
standard email quote-marks.  Thanx.

Saluta,

Robin

>JOINING SIGNS 'and', ';' [; e] The semi colon indicates the end of one 
>sentence but which is joined to another, 'e' also joins two sentences. 
>'e' can also join words into phrases 'land and sea' so the semicolon can 
>distinguish between the two uses.
>As the sentence is joined to the one before, a capital is not used.
>[S]    its money [id valuta]
>[V]    is [es]
>[O]    the west carribean dollar [un Orienta Karibean Dolar.]
>   ***** Because glosa does not make much distinction between nouns,
verbs, adjectives etc, slight confusions can arise. As 'id valuta' stands, 
'id' could be a pronoun and 'valuta' a verb [it cashes .... a cheque]. 
However, the following 'es' makes this very unlikely. in 'U id valuta', 
'U' introduces a noun phrase so that the 'id' modifies 'valuta' - 'its 
money' ****
>
>'St. Lucia  pa gene krati 14 kron inter plu France-pe e England-pe pre 
id pa gene libe tem 1979.' 
>
>[S]        St Lucia
>[V]       [past tense] got governed  [pa gene krati]
>'Pa' introduces the verb and indicates the past tense, 'gene' is the 
>equivalent of the English passive.
>EXTRA[X]   14 times [14 kron] a time phrase modifting the verb phrase.
>[O]        between French people and English people [plu France-pe e 
>England-pe]
>JOINING WORD  pre [before] joins the main sentence above to the one 
>following
>[S]          id [it]    no capital
>[V]          got liberated  [pa gene libe]
>[X]          in 1979 [tem 1979], a time phrase
>

At 01:43 PM 12/24/02 EST, Sid wrote:
>a parallel investigation into the developing of munada linugu
>SG
>'Tem pre oligo meno plu nova-papira-pe e komerci-pe pa dice de u ski de plu 
>lingua in Englanda.'
>
>ml:-
>'teme pere oligo meno, lu pe-papira-nova e pe-komerici pa dice de u siki de 
>lu linugu in Enege-lanada - ' 
>
>here the head  word [oligo, pe, dice] follows the intro word  [teme, pere,
plu 
>pa u] and a word is modified by the word after it. this is completely 
>different from glosa but it makes it much easier to find the head.
*  There is an interesting conceptual conflict going on.
   For me the understanding of Glosa follows from the rather traditional
ideas of phrases and clauses, and the functioning of the words that make
them up.
   As an extra level of syntax understanding, the more 'Functional Grammar'
idea of the "head" word of a phrase solidified this for me.  But, I see the
'head' of a NOUN PHRASE as the main NOUN; and the 'head' of a VERB PHRASE
as the main VERB.  And then, when it finally came to me, that Ron Clark's
dictum, "A word is modified by its precedent," leads to a fairly clear-cut
'head-final' structure in the phrases, things fell into place.
   So, it is mystifying to me that Sid does not recognise the final word in
a phrase as the 'head' of that phrase.  As I see it, the phrase builds in
semantic power from the least significant word at the start, to the most
semantically significant word at the end: this last word is the 'head.'

  And, without being unkind, nor through calling upon another lqanguage, I
would expand Wendy's ADVERBIAL PHRASE, 'Tem pre oligo meno,' to make the
time relationship painfully clear: 

                  ~Tem plu previo oligo meno, ... ~
            /          /      \       \     \
 [for,during] [all of the] [previous] [few] [months]

   Each word contributes to the full modification of the central VERB
~dice~, and the logic of the situation tells us that the order is fairly
set, in that we cannot change the order without causing the phrase to sound
odd.  This logic is based on the notion that each successive word is more
semantically important that the last,
   IE re time --> countable --> before now --> quantity --> unit of time

   It can be said that I believe there is a full sentence from which words
might be elided to make up a more vernacular version of Glosa.  It can also
be said that I feel learners ought to be taught to use the 'full version'
of Glosa before they start to move to a more elided version of the language.
   This expanded Glosa might be described as the more 'discursive' mode of
the language; while Ron Clark often mentioned the 'telegramatic' use of
Glosa, I feel that such an abbreviated usage should come only with a clear
understanding of the words we are leaving out. 
   
>the comma indicates that the previous phrase is EXTRA and that the next is 
>SUBJECT
*  This is only fair to the reader: puctuation is an indication of the
syntactic units of the sentence.  While "EXTRA" might be meaningful to Sid,
the WHO, WHAT, WHERE, WHEN, WHY and HOW answered by ADVERBIAL PHRASES and
ADVERBIAL CLAUSES have more analytical value for me.  I saw this more as a
"WHEN phrase"  than as an "EXTRA phrase."

  While some people have receive no grammatical training during English
lessons, and thus have no framework for their understanding of Glosa, the
necessary grammatical information can be introduced through properly graded
Glosa instruction.  We might be getting there.

Saluta, 

Robin Gaskell

*  Hi Sid, 
   This is one way of "doing" interlinguistics.
   Have to admit, it reminds me of the "nonsense sylables" I learnt were
being used to test people's learning ability.
   Actually I am not very intelligent when it comes to memorising 'nonsense
sylables,' so I gave a complete miss to the whole segment of a-priori
designed languages.  I would say that it would be impossible for me to
learn an a-priori language, so I didn't even consider trying.
   I am an example of someone who needs to understand what he is learning:
this translates into my interest in the etymology of words; as long as I
can find a story behind a word - where it came from, what primitive root it
is based on, etc - I can store that word away .. with its story attached.
I guess I might have been pretty dumb had I been shipwrecked off the
Chinese coast, and brought up to remember hundreds of sounds that were
unrelated to their written forms.
   When I was told the story of Glosa, I thought that it could work for me,
because I had come in contact with some of the Classical roots during my
education in Agriculture, and also because of their being a major part of
the history of English.  While I am not good with languages, I do get
letters to the editor, in English, printed in the paper.
   So, yes, everyone has slightly different versions of the language
ability, and I would have been right up against it, were I to have grown up
in a non-Indo-European culture, and tried to learn Glosa.

   Although Glosa's reliance on the Classical roots might be a disadvantage
to those outside the Indo-European tradition, it surely gives a head-start
to people with a European background, or a history of scientific, or
Classical, study.  The 'nonsense sylable' approach to planned languages
gives no-one an advantage, and puts some, like me, at a distinct disadvantage.

Saluta,

Robin Gaskell

Continuing:

The problem with Glosa is that it's rough and unfinished,
and doesn't work right linguistically. Most of the other
people participating in this group have grown dissatisfied
with Glosa and want to reform it, the remainder are unable
to write anything comprehensible in it. This includes the
authors, whose samples are/were mere idiomatic relexes that
cannot be understood by non-English speakers. But there is
real merit to the basic idea of using an analytic grammar
with latinate roots, as in the Lingua Franca. Unfortunately
there's no other existing language like that, except Glosa.

(Peano's Interlingua was absorbed into Occidental, which
has many analytic features but still relies on suffixes.)
I use Occ quite a bit for international correspondence, but
would still like to see Glosa reformed and revived to act as
a global interlingua, something acceptable outside Europe.
This doesn't seem the least bit likely to happen, though.
It would require that Wendy appoint a group to carry on
Glosa development, particularly now that she is inactive.

Any language will evolve over time to cover any deficiencies
felt by its speakers in daily use. Glosa could do likewise
with a sufficient community of users; Esperanto accomplished
this to a great extent, adding latinate roots that Zamenhof
(Espo's creator) resisted. I just don't have 100 years to
wait for it to evolve far enough (or 1000 years for Glosa).

It all leaves Glosa nowhere, and this group unusable for a
discussion of possible reforms, because of outside agitators
like the mad-dog Jay, and a few loyal diehards who can't
use it but don't want it changed either.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] global majority
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Mon, 30 Dec 2002 00:04:13 -0800

Around 90% of the world's languages usually place the subject
before the predicate. But only half put the direct object after
the verb. And only half put the noun after the adjective. Among
just the euro-based languages, the proportions remain similar.
So any auxiliary language that chooses (just 1 of the 4 orders),
loses (its claim as a world language).

It is easy to mark the beginning of a verb phrase or direct object
with a particle, which allows their positions to be interchanged
without loss of intelligibility. And swapping the positions of
adjectives and nouns leads to no fatal confusion, even without
adding particles to remove all ambiguity. In fact, most languages
do not maintain a full and separate category for what we call
adjectives in English. (So there is no need for p.o.s. marking.)

This can be easily fixed in Glosa, as long as every verb phrase
is initiated by one of the tense/aspect/mood/voice particles
and every noun phrase begins with an article or preposition.
Also, adverbs of manner (ablatives etc) should be rendered as
prepositional noun phrases, not squeezed into the verb phrase.
Word order is then nearly as flexible as Esperanto, but simpler.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] global majority, con't
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Mon, 30 Dec 2002 11:32:36 -0800

The aim of any auxiliary lang must be maximum ease of learning
with sufficiently powerful expressiveness (not the reverse).
This begins with the alphabet, both spelling and pronunciation.

After a lot of experimentation I keep returning to the same
conclusion, that Glosa has too many sounds and spellings,
owing to its inherited Greek bias. Taking Italian/Spanish as
models for consonant reduction, we can eliminate troublesome
letters (H J K Q W X Y Z) and the more difficult sounds.
The resulting phonology would be very acceptable globally.

There are approx 6000 CVCV roots common to Romance langs
(and most IALs). They can be generated automatically by
an impartial machine algorithm, and re-run to update the
vocabulary as often as desired. Ambiguities are resolved
where possible. (A bit of routine hand-tuning might help,
but we don't need to rely on some great leader's genius.
Instead we can let common collective usage decide matters.)

A pure CVCV vocabulary is better adapted to compounding.
The uniform word-shape is more fluent and dignified.
It lacks the immediate recognizability of longer words
(in Occidental/etc) but has considerable mnemonic value.

Esperanto's severe disfigurement of international roots
and the many silly arbitrary choices of the current vocab
can thus be avoided/repaired. The result seems already
sufficient for real-world use, certainly much improved
versus the current Glosa set (about 33% is identical).

BTW, it turns out that CVC is really insufficient, so the
Ido/Esperanto trick of using p.o.s. final vowels can't work.
CVCVC gives slightly nicer roots (e.g. FELIN vs GATO) but
seems too heavy and invites suffixation. And adding more
consonants (e.g. H J) yields very few roots while excluding
very many people who can't pronounce or distinguish them.

To: glosalist{at}lists{dot}zeta{dot}org{dot}au
Subject: [glosalist] global majority, #3
From: Charles{at}Catty{dot}Com
Date: Tue, 31 Dec 2002 10:47:04 -0800

Only the minimum necessary grammatical apparatus can be
sufficiently simple for adults to learn in their limited
free time. Fewer than 100 particles are needed for a
workable analytical language, so they can and should
all follow a CV pattern, distinguishing them from the
CVCV roots at a glance. They mark off phrase boundaries
and together with a few sentence patterns (syntax rules)
they can essentially implement the whole grammar, without
resorting to painful nonsense like "parts of speech".

Glosa's set of particles is unacceptable and incomplete.
They need to be selected from the natural source languages
rather than invented; no language inventor is more ingenious
than the hundreds of millions who together evolved the
Romance languages during 2 millenia of real life. All the
necessary particles are well-known to linguists, who have
described the same or similar functions in nearly every
language yet discovered. We just need to collect them.

I don't have an algorithm for that, though -- and not
knowing Greek Latin etc, I can't make the selections.
Maybe a pidgin stage would help to sort them out.

End of suggestions. Happy New Year, brave new world.
